Sec. 25-12. - Procedure for granting new and transferred local business tax receipts. 
    All applications for new or transferred local business tax receipts within the city shall be granted only if the use or occupation being applied for complies with all applicable city land use, zoning, building and fire codes related to that specific occupation. 
(Ord. No. 2007-01, § 1, 1-31-2007) 
Sec. 25-13. - Changes in terminology relative to Local Business Tax Act (formerly Occupational License Tax Act). 
    Where there is a reference to "Occupational License Tax Act" anywhere else in this Code, the Code shall be read to mean "Local Business Tax Act" in its stead, and any reference to the "occupational license tax certificate" shall be read to mean "local business tax receipt." 
(Ord. No. 2007-01, § 1, 1-31-2007) 
Chapter 26 - PARKING OF NONCOMMERCIAL VEHICLES USED FOR RECREATIONAL PURPOSES AND COMMERCIAL VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-2, § 20, adopted Feb. 16, 2011, amended the title of [former] Ch. 22 to read as herein set out [as Ch. 26]. Formerly, Ch. 22 was titled Parking of Noncommercial Vehicles Used for Recreational Purposes. 
Cross reference- Trailer park or automobile tourist park, occupational license tax, § 25-29(220); building permit fees, § 9-21(61) et seq.; trailer and mobile home mounting, § 9-33 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases when used in this section shall have the following meanings: 
    All-terrain vehicles (ATVs). Any open motor vehicle having one (1) seat and three (3) or more wheels that is fitted with large tires and chiefly designed for use on off-road and/or rugged terrain. This definition is intended to include buggies, quad bikes, all-terrain motorcycles, tricycles and any other vehicle designed for off-road use. 
    Boat. Any contrivance designed to be propelled through the water or any boat so licensed by the state. 
    Bus. Any self-propelled, rubber-tired vehicle designed to accommodate or capable of accommodating ten (10) or more passengers and so licensed and registered for operation on public streets. 
    Camping trailer or motor home. Any vehicle or portable structure designed primarily to provide temporary living quarters for recreation, camping or travel use; either a vehicular structure mounted on wheels, self-powered or designed to be pulled by another vehicle or a structure designed to be mounted upon and carried by another vehicle or trailer. This definition is intended to include motor homes, travel trailers, camping trailer, camp bus or house bus and truck-camper unit of walk-in capacity. 
    Commercial lettering. Any letters, pictures, numbers, logos, symbols or combinations thereof which advertise or identify a trade, business, industry, or other activity for a profit, or a product, commodity or service. The term shall not include bumper stickers affixed to bumpers only, the brand name or the decal or plate commonly applied by a motor vehicle dealer or manufacturer. 
    Commercial vehicle. Any bus, step van, truck, trailer, utility trailer, truck tractor, tow truck or wrecker, agricultural, construction or industrial equipment or any vehicles designed, intended or used for transportation of people, goods or things for profit, or any vehicle displaying commercial lettering. The terms shall include but shall not necessarily be limited to a pick-up truck with altered cargo box, or from which the cargo box has been removed. Any vehicle with tools, building materials, merchandise or outfitted with emergency flashing or rotating lights visible from the street or from abutting residential property shall be deemed a commercial vehicle. 
    Commercial zone. Shall include any property with a zoning designation of B-1, B-2, B-3, B-2A, TOC-CC, TOC-G, TOC-C. Any property with a TOC designation consisting of one hundred (100) per cent residential development shall not be considered commercially zoned property. 
    Full-track vehicle. Any vehicle containing an endless chain-track drive system that propels a vehicle and where wheels are not utilized. 
    Half-track vehicle. Any vehicle containing an endless chain-track drive system that propels a vehicle supported in front by a pair of wheels. 
    Limousine. Any automobile with two (2) axles other than a standard sedan or coupe which is designed to accommodate, or capable of accommodating, less than ten (10) passengers. A limousine shall not display any commercial lettering. 
    Motorcycle. Any a two-wheeled vehicle, with the two (2) wheels in line, powered by an engine, on which a rider sits astride and steers by handlebars. The definition shall also include motorcycles with sidecars or any three-wheeled variations powered by a single engine. 
    Motor scooter. Any two-wheeled vehicle with small wheels and a low-powered gasoline engine geared to the rear wheel. This definition is intended to include all makes and models of motorized bicycles, scooters, mopeds, or other motorized two-wheeled vehicles with engines up to two hundred fifty (250) ccs. 
    Noncommercial vehicle used for recreational purposes. Any vehicle that does not meet the size and structure requirements of a commercial vehicle as specified in this section, and only used for leisure or recreational purposes including boats, personal watercraft, trailers, utility trailers, horse trailers, recreational vehicles (RVs), motor homes, campers, motorcycles, motor scooters, golf carts, go-carts, half track vehicles, full-track vehicles, swamp buggies, or any other vehicle that is not used for any commercial enterprise or purpose and does not display commercial lettering. 
    Overnight parking shall mean leaving the vehicle parked at any time between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the following morning. 
    Personal watercraft. Any watercraft a rider sits or stands on, rather than sits inside of, that includes an inboard engine driving a pump jet, which is powered by a two- or four-stroke engine. This definition is intended to include jet skis and all other makes and models of personal watercraft seating at least one (1) or up to three (3) people. 
    Pickup truck shall mean any motor vehicle designed primarily for the transportation of property within a permanently attached cargo box. Any pickup truck wherein the cab or cargo box has been altered or enlarged to facilitate the transportation of people, items, or goods for commercial purposes shall be deemed a truck, and not a pick-up truck, pursuant to these definitions. 
    Swamp buggy. A vehicle used to negotiate swampy terrain, either: 
(1)  An amphibious four-wheel drive tractor; or 
(2)  A flat-bottomed boat driven by an airplane propeller. 
    Tow truck or wrecker shall mean any self-powered vehicle manufactured with the capability to be utilized or which is actually utilized for the purpose of towing or transporting automobiles, trucks or buses. 
    Trailer. An open vehicular structure mounted on wheels designed to be pulled by another vehicle designed and intended to transport boats or recreational vehicles, swamp buggies, half-track vehicles, and full-track vehicles. 
    Truck shall mean any motor vehicle designed or used principally for the carriage of goods and includes a motor vehicle to which has been added a cabinet box, a platform, a rack, or other equipment for the purposes of carrying goods. 
    Truck tractor shall mean any motor vehicle which is designed for or equipped with a fifth wheel hitch for drawing semitrailers or any other form of trailer. It shall not include pickup trucks equipped with a fifth-wheel hitch. 
    Utility trailer shall mean an enclosed vehicular structure without its own motive power designed and/or used for the transportation of goods or materials. 
    Van shall mean any motor vehicle having a generally rectangular bulk, which is licensed and registered for operation upon public streets and which has a length not exceeding twenty-one (21) feet. 
(Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-6-1988; Ord. No. 2005-12, § 2, 9-21-2005; Ord. No. 2006-04, § 1, 5-17-2006; Ord. No. 2011-2, § 20, 2-16-2011) 
Cross reference- Supplemental local regulations-Parking of commercial vehicles, § 33-69.52(4); Streets and sidewalks, Ch. 35. 
Sec. 26-2. - Commercial vehicles. 
(a)  Commercial vehicles in commercial zones. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful to park any commercial vehicle in any commercial zone of the city (or any commercial portion of a PUD zone) unless said vehicle is an accessory use to a bona fide commercial use presently existing on the same site or plot within the zone where said vehicle is parked. Parking for customers and individuals doing business with an establishment for which parking is provided shall constitute an accessory use under this provision, and therefore shall not be prohibited. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful to park any bus, truck tractor or utility trailer overnight, in any area, including the public rights-of-way and private property, in any commercial zone of the city or commercial portion of a PUD zone, except as provided in subsection (a)(1) or (a)(4). 
(3)  Any property owner shall be deemed in violation of subsection (a) if a vehicle as above provided has been parked or is standing on the property owned by him/her overnight. 
(4)  This subsection shall not apply to any vehicles parked in garages, service stations, repair shops, motel parking lots, storage and parking areas of public utility facilities when vehicles are being repaired, sold, rented or otherwise used for a purpose of the preceding businesses. 
(b)  Commercial vehicles in industrial zones . The parking of commercial vehicles on industrial zoned properties shall comply with all provisions of appendix A, Zoning, articles XXIV and XXV, and section 3.10.1. 
(c)  Commercial vehicles in zones other than commercial and industrial. 
(1)  [Prohibited acts.] It shall be unlawful to park or stand any commercial vehicle at any time, in any area, including the public streets and rights-of-way and private property, within the city that is zoned other than commercial or industrial. The parking of such commercial vehicles in an unauthorized zoning district is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. Any property owner shall be deemed in violation of this subsection if a commercial vehicle has been parked or is standing on the property owned by him/her. 
(2)  Permissive parking. Notwithstanding the prohibition in the preceding paragraph, there may be parked in any district which is zoned R-1, R-1A-D, R-2, R-3, R-3A, R-3U, T-1, PRC, residential portions of a PUD district, or TOC-CC, TOC-G, and TOC-C properties that are one hundred (100) per cent residential, on a plot improved with a permitted structure, the following commercial vehicles: 
a.  Standard sedans, coupes, and other automobiles designed by the manufacturer primarily for noncommercial uses; 
b.  Station wagons or similar type of motor vehicle; 
c.  Minivans, sport utility vehicles, and vans designed by the manufacturer primarily for noncommercial uses; or 
d.  Pickup truck; 
e.  Limousines, subject to the following: 
i.  Only one (1) limousine shall be allowed per residence which is owned either by the property owner or resident, or by his/her employer; 
ii.  There shall still continue to be room on the property for the parking of two (2) additional vehicles as provided under the City Code in addition to any limousine parked on the property. 
(3)  No vehicles permitted above shall have more than two (2) axles. 
(4)  No vehicle permitted above shall be greater than twenty-three (23) feet in length nor greater than nine and two-tenths (9.2) feet in height above ground or the surface on which it is situated. 
(5)  No vehicle permitted above may be parked on any public right-of-way, lawn, or yard, and shall only be parked on a driveway, or an area constructed and permitted by the building department of the city for the parking of vehicles. 
(d)  Exemptions. There shall be excepted from subsections (a) through (c) above: 
(1)  Any emergency vehicle or vehicle necessary for service by any public utility. 
(2)  Commercial vehicles necessary for service to any individual or structure during the time said service is actually being performed. 
(3)  Any commercial vehicle of any size which is parked in a wholly enclosed garage or structure where no portion or part of said commercial vehicle is visible or protruding from said structure. 
(e)  Violations. The following shall be liable for any violations of this section: 
(1)  Any person, association or corporation listed on the title certificate or other record of ownership of any commercial vehicle or agricultural, construction or industrial equipment contained therein; 
(2)  Any person, association or corporation which is the owner of the real property upon which the commercial vehicle is found, according to the latest ad valorem tax record of Broward County; 
(3)  Any person, association or corporation provided as a tenant under any rental agreement or any person, association or corporation which is in possession and control of rental property upon which a vehicle is found. 
(Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-6-1988; Ord. No. 2011-2, § 21, 2-16-2011) 
Sec. 26-3. - Parking regulations for noncommercial vehicles used for recreational purposes. 
(a)  The parking of any noncommercial vehicle(s) used for recreational purposes listed in this chapter shall be permitted in any residentially zoned district of the city, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  Said vehicle(s) shall be parked only on the property which is the residence or place of abode of the owner of said vehicle. 
(2)  Said vehicle(s) which, pursuant to state law, must be registered or licensed, shall have a current registration and/or license. 
(3)  Said vehicle(s) shall not be parked on any public dedicated street, sidewalk or right-of-way (including any swale or parkway). 
(4)  Said vehicle(s) shall be parked only in backyards or side yards such that no portion of the vehicle protrudes past, or in front of facades of any residence. 
As an exception to the immediately preceding paragraph, a noncommercial vehicle(s) may be parked in any driveway or any area constructed and permitted by the building department of the city. 
(5)  Said vehicle(s) shall not display commercial lettering nor have any equipment, materials, or devices associated with a commercial or industrial use visible. The existence of such lettering, equipment, materials or devices shall automatically deem the vehicle as a "commercial vehicle," subject to the provisions of section 26-2 above. 
(6)  Said vehicle(s) shall not exceed thirty-five (35) feet in length from the front to the back. 
(b)  The parking of any noncommercial vehicle(s) used for recreational purposes listed in this chapter shall be prohibited in any nonresidential zoning district, unless the property whereon said vehicle is parked contains a bona fide business involving the sales, storage, or repair of such vehicle(s). Parking for customers and individuals doing business with an establishment for which parking is provided shall constitute an accessory use under this provision, and therefore shall not be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-6-1988; Ord. No. 2002-14, § 1, 10-2-2002; Ord. No. 2005-12, § 2, 9-21-2005; Ord. No. 2006-04, § 1, 5-17-2006; Ord. No. 2011-2, § 22, 2-16-2011) 
Sec. 26-4. - Exemptions. 
    The following are exempt from sections 26-1, 26-2 and 26-3: 
(1)  Any noncommercial vehicle(s) used for recreational purposes which are parked within a wholly enclosed garage or structure where no portion or part of said is visible or protruding from said structure. 
(2)  Recreational vehicles within areas zoned RVRP Recreational Vehicle Resort Park District. 
(Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-6-1988; Ord. No. 2005-12, § 2, 9-21-2005; Ord. No. 2006-04, § 1, 5-17-2006; Ord. No. 1500.551, § 6, 8-19-2009; Ord. No. 2011-2, § 23, 2-16-2011) 
Sec. 26-5. - Prohibited. 
    Storing, keeping, or parking of any tanks, or military vehicles, the manufacture or alteration of which is for military purposes is specifically prohibited within the city. 
(Ord. No. 88-1, § 1, 1-6-1988; Ord. No. 2005-12, § 2, 9-21-2005; Ord. No. 2006-04, § 1, 5-17-2006; Ord. No. 2011-2, § 24, 2-16-2011) 
Sec. 26-6. - Prohibitions. 
    At no time shall a camping trailer or motor home, or any other recreational vehicle that is permitted to be parked, pursuant to this section, in a residential district be used as a permanent or temporary residence. 
(Ord. No. 2005-12, § 2, 9-21-2005) 
Secs. 26-7-26-10. - Reserved.

Chapter 27 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 80-6, § 1, adopted Jan. 2, 1980, amended [former] Ch. 15 in its entirety to read as herein set out [as Ch. 27] in §§ 27-1-27-6. The provisions in former Ch. 15, §§ 15-1-15-6, concerning parks, were derived from Ord. No. 200.34, §§ 1-8, adopted Nov. 11, 1970. 
Cross reference- City designated a bird sanctuary, § 6-1; littering prohibited, § 19-10; parks or recreational areas required in plats for certain subdivisions, § 31-19(E); streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 35; abandonment of city property, § 35-0.1. 

Sec. 27-1. - Parks supervised by recreation director. 
    All parks in the city shall be operated and maintained under the supervision of the parks and recreation director. He shall perform his duties subject to the supervision of the city manager. 
    The director of the parks and recreation department shall have the right with the approval of the city manager to make whatever rules and regulations are necessary for the proper utilization and protection of all city recreation facilities and property. 
(Ord. No. 80-6, § 1, 1-2-1980) 
Sec. 27-2. - Opening and closing hours; closing sections of parks. 
    The hours of operation for all city parks shall be as follows: Parks shall be open to the public daily from sunup to sunset, except where written permission is granted by the parks and recreation director. It shall be unlawful for any person or persons other than city personnel conducting business therein to occupy or be present in said park during any hours in which the park is not open to the public. 
    Any section or part of any park may be declared closed to the public by the parks and recreation director at any time and for any interval of time, either temporary or at regular stated intervals. 
(Ord. No. 80-6, § 1, 1-2-1980) 
Sec. 27-3. - Rules and regulations for facilities. 
    The following rules and regulations will govern the use of the various recreation facilities: 
(a)  Teen center and David Park Pavilion: 
(1)  Ninety-five (95) per cent of the membership of any group must be Margate residents. 
(2)  Authorized representative of group will sign for key. No copies of key shall be made under any circumstances. 
(3)  No group will exceed the maximum occupancy of the facility established by the fire marshal: Pavilion, fifty-four (54) persons; teen center, two hundred twenty-two (222) persons. 
(4)  Groups will be responsible for turning off lights, air conditioner, public address systems and lock up. 
(5)  Groups will be liable for any damages incurred. 
(6)  No alcoholic beverages without approval of city manager. 
(b)  Ballfields and concession stands: 
(1)  Ninety-five (95) per cent of membership of any group must be Margate residents. However, this shall not apply to the combined Margate-North Lauderdale Football Club. 
(2)  Baseball and softball may be played only where there is a baseball diamond with a backstop. 
(3)  Ballfield lights will be turned on and off by parks and recreation staff only. Lights will be utilized only during hours approved by the parks and recreation director. 
(4)  Concession stands will be operated according to city and county health standards and may be inspected at any time. 
(5)  The parks and recreation director may set limits on league enrollment. 
(c)  Tennis courts: 
(1)  For use by Margate residents and their guests only. 
(2)  Shall be open as determined by resolution of the city commission. 
(3)  Reservations are accepted only for tournaments. 
(4)  Use of courts is on a first-come, first-serve basis. If people are waiting to use the courts, play will be limited to one (1) hour. 
(5)  No one may receive money for lessons or instruction at city tennis courts unless approved by parks and recreation director. 
(d)  Royal Palm Pool: 
(1)  Pool is for use of Margate residents and their guests only. 
(2)  Persons using pool must abide by the posted rules and regulations. 
(3)  Pool fees shall be established by the city commission. 
(e)  Lemon Tree Lake: 
(1)  Permitted water craft. 
a.  Sail boats and similar sail powered craft (no auxiliary power). 
b.  Row boats and other similar manually powered craft. 
c.  Water craft powered by electric motors with fifty (50) or less pounds of thrust. 
(2)  Prohibited water craft. All boats or similar craft which are powered by internal combustion motors. 
(3)  Swimming. There shall be no swimming nor bathing allowed in Lemon Tree Lake. 
(4)  Docks. In order to provide for uniform construction around Lemon Tree Lake, docks shall only be installed pursuant to the plans and instructions obtainable at the department of environmental and engineering services which have been approved by such department. To the extent that the preceding plans and instructions deviate from section 35-16 of this Code, the approved plans and instructions shall govern. 
(5)  Fences. No fences shall be allowed around Lemon Tree Lake. 
(Ord. No. 80-6, § 1, 1-2-1980; Ord. No. 81-49, § 1, 9-23-1981; Ord. No. 94-8, § 1, 5-4-1994; Ord. No. 97-3, § 1, 2-19-1997; Ord. No. 2007-17, § 1, 8-29-2007) 
Sec. 27-4. - Permits for use of recreation facilities. 
    To reserve the above recreational facilities, any group, organization, league or individuals wishing to reserve recreation facilities must fill out an application for a facility use permit at the parks and recreation office. The parks and recreation director will review the application and grant a permit if the facility is available and the activity is deemed beneficial to the citizens of Margate. Copies of all permits shall be on file with the police department. 
    Any facility which has not been reserved is available to Margate residents on a first-come, first-serve basis. 
(Ord. No. 80-6, § 1, 1-2-1980) 
Sec. 27-5. - General rules and regulations. 
(a)  Alcoholic beverages. No alcoholic beverages are allowed in any parks without approval of city manager. 
(b)  Trash, fires. People using the parks will be responsible for placing all trash in the proper receptacles, and extinguishing fires in barbeque areas. 
(c)  Motor vehicles. All vehicles shall park in designated areas. No motor driven vehicles shall be allowed in city parks except for city vehicles performing authorized work or vehicles authorized by the parks and recreation director. 
(d)  Dogs. No dogs shall be allowed in parks except for Seeing Eye dogs, dogs used by law enforcement officials or in the case of special events, i.e., dog shows. 
(e)  Golfing. No golfing is allowed in any city parks. 
(Ord. No. 80-6, § 1, 1-2-1980) 
Sec. 27-6. - Penalty for violation of rules and regulations. 
(a)  Expulsion. Any individual or group of individuals which violate any rules or regulations set out herein or promulgated by the parks and recreation department or any lawful order of any employee of the parks and recreation department made for the protection of the persons or property at any city recreation facility shall have no right to remain at the city recreation facility at which said violation or disobedience occurred for the remainder of the day in which said violation or disobedience occurred. Any individual or group of individuals remaining at said facility will be considered trespassing and shall be subject to ejection or arrest by the police department. 
(b)  Denial of use of facilities. Any individual or group of individuals which repeatedly violate the rules set forth herein or promulgated by the parks and recreation department or any lawful order of any employee of the parks and recreation department made for the protection of the persons or property at any city recreation facility may be permanently barred from all city parks and recreation facilities upon the order of the city manager with the advice of the director of parks and recreation department. Any individual or group of individuals permanently barred shall be considered trespassing upon any public facility of the parks and recreation department and shall be subject to ejection and arrest by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 80-6, § 1, 1-2-1980) 
Sec. 27-7. - Fees for facilities and services. 
    Fees for all parks and recreation facilities and services shall be set by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 80-37, § 1, 6-4-1980) 
Sec. 27-8. - Background checks of adults involved in youth sports leagues. 
(a)  State and national criminal background check. The local level governing board of a sports league that utilizes any city facility, court, or playing field shall ensure that adults associated with that league shall undergo a state and national criminal background check. The background check program requirements and parameters are set forth below, and shall be available in the parks and recreation department administrative office. 
(b)  Failure to mandate a state and national criminal background check. Any sports league that fails to mandate and complete a state and national criminal background check in a timely manner by deadlines established in subsection (h) below, as certified by the parks and recreation department, shall be prohibited from utilizing any city facility, court, or playing field. 
(c)  Type of background check that shall be conducted. A thorough state and national background check that identifies an individual's entire criminal history shall be conducted. The background check shall focus only on offenses that most directly impact both the children and the adults which include but are not limited to the following: 
(1)  Any activity of a sexual nature that involves, pertains to, or is directed at a minor. 
(2)  Acts of violence. 
(3)  Acts of lewd or lascivious behavior. 
(4)  Drug possession and/or drug distribution. 
(5)  Public intoxication, repeated. 
The local level governing board shall determine the timeline parameters regarding when an offense occurred versus the resulting impact on the individual. 
(d)  Individuals who shall be subject to a background check. All adult managers and coaches, adult assistant managers and coaches, all adult concession stand workers, and any other adult regardless of title or designation who has more than an occasional league-related interaction with a child. 
(e)  Responsibility for ensuring that a background check is conducted. The local level governing board of the league shall ensure that the background checks are conducted. 
(f)  Frequency of conducting a background check. 
(1)  Every adult who is new to a city youth sports league shall be subject to an initial background check that shall be completed prior to that adult's involvement in any capacity. 
(2)  A background check shall be conducted every three (3) years. 
(3)  An adult who has a more than a three-year break between background checks shall be considered as being new to that league and shall be subject to a background check. 
(g)  Responsibility for payment of costs incurred to conduct background checks. All background check related costs shall be the sole responsibility of the league. In the event that an adult is involved in more than one (1) sports league, the respective leagues should work together to share the costs in a mutually beneficial manner. 
(h)  Notification to the city regarding compliance with and results of background checks. Prior to the start of each year's practice season, the local level governing board of the league shall submit written certification to the city parks and recreation department that the league has complied with the city commission's directives regarding background checks on all adults new to the league and also all adults previous league experience. 
    The certifying document shall be signed by the local level governing board members or league officers. 
    The certifying document shall read: 
"In accordance with and pursuant to Chapter 27 of the Margate Code, the (League Name) has received a completed background check on the individuals listed below. All listed individuals have passed a state and national background check on the areas designated by the City." 
(i)  Responsibility of records maintenance, ownership, and control. Maintenance, ownership, control of all background check records and information generated, received, possessed and stored shall be the sole responsibility of the league. 
(Ord. No. 2002-13, § 1, 10-2-2002) 
Chapter 29 - PENSIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 29-1. - Extension of social security benefits. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the City of Margate, Florida, to extend, effective as of April 1, 1961, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law nor excepted herein, the benefits of the system of Old Age and Survivors Insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, and by Chapter 650, Florida Statutes, as amended; and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in Section 650.02, Florida Statutes, performed in the employ of said City of Margate by employees and officials thereof, except legal services. 
(Ord. No. 1800.00, § 1, 5-10-1961) 
Sec. 29-2. - Agreements with state; execution by mayor. 
    The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the Florida Industrial Commission [Department of Commerce] as state agency, for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by said system of Old Age and Survivors Insurance to the employees and officials of this city as provided in this chapter, which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by this city as are found by the state agency to be necessary and proper, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed on and after the first day of April, A. D., 1961. 
(Ord. No. 1800.00, § 3, 5-10-1961) 
Sec. 29-3. - Withholdings from salaries. 
    Withholdings from salaries, wages or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 29-1 are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made, in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by said laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Ord. No. 1800.00, § 4, 5-10-1961) 
Sec. 29-4. - Contribution by city. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from the general fund, such amounts, at such times, as may be required to pay promptly the contributions and assessments required of the city as employer by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated state agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Ord. No. 1800.00, § 5, 5-10-1961) 
Sec. 29-5. - Records and reports. 
    The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall adhere to the regulations of the state agency. 
(Ord. No. 1800.00, § 6, 5-10-1961) 
Sec. 29-6. - Adoption of terms of Social Security Act. 
    The city does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of Title II of the Social Security Act as amended, for and on behalf of all officers and employees of its departments and agencies to be covered under the agreement. 
(Ord. No. 1800.00, § 6, 5-10-1961) 
Sec. 29-7. - City treasurer custodian of funds; records; reports. 
    The city treasurer is hereby designated the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees and of the appropriated funds for the contribution of the City of Margate, and the city clerk is hereby made the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining personnel records for the purposes of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1800.00, § 7, 5-10-1961) 
Secs. 29-8-29-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RETIREMENT SYSTEM[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 73-16, §§ 1-7, adopted July 11, 1973, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion herein as Art. II, §§ 29-16-29-22, was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 29-16. - Participation in Florida Retirement System. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the City of Margate, Florida, to conduct a referendum on the 28th day of June, 1973, among eligible officers and employees for the purpose of permitting said officers and employees to elect to participate in the Florida Retirement System as authorized by Chapter 121, Florida Statutes, and amendments thereto, whereupon all those officers and employees, except those excluded by law, electing by affirmative vote in said referendum to participate in the Florida Retirement System, shall become members of the Florida Retirement System effective on the 1st day of August, 1973, and shall participate thereafter during their employment, and those officers and employees who elect not to participate in the Florida Retirement System shall sign an appropriate rejection ballot which shall be attached to and become a part of the agreement with the state for providing coverage under the Florida Retirement System. Those officers and employees electing not to participate in the Florida Retirement System who were members of a local retirement system on the date of the referendum, shall be permitted to continue their membership in the local retirement system for as long as their employment continues. 
    All officers and employees hired on and after the date of the referendum shall be compulsory members of the Florida Retirement System as of the effective date of participation in the Florida Retirement System so stated herein. 
(Ord. No. 73-16, § 1, 7-11-1973) 
Sec. 29-17. - Implementation of plan. 
    The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the department of administration for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by the Florida Retirement System to the employees and officials of the city as provided in sections 29-16 and 29-17 hereof, which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by said City of Margate as are found by the administrator of the Florida Retirement System to be necessary and proper, and shall be effective with respect to any employment covered by such agreement for services performed on and after the 1st day of August, 1973. 
(Ord. No. 73-16, § 2, 7-11-1973) 
Sec. 29-18. - Withholdings. 
    Withholdings from salaries, wages, or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 29-16 hereof are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made, in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the administrator designated by said laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Ord. No. 73-16, § 3, 7-11-1973) 
Sec. 29-19. - Appropriations for payment to system. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from general revenue and employee's contributions such amounts and at such times as may be required to pay promptly the contributions and assessments required of the City of Margate which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated administrator of the Florida Retirement System at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Ord. No. 73-16, § 4, 7-11-1973) 
Sec. 29-20. - Keeping records, reports. 
    The City of Margate shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state laws or regulations, and shall adhere to all laws and regulations relating to the Florida Retirement System. 
(Ord. No. 73-16, § 5, 7-11-1973) 
Sec. 29-21. - Adoption. 
    The City of Margate does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of the Florida Retirement System, for and on behalf of all officers and employees of its departments and agencies to be covered under the agreement. 
(Ord. No. 73-16, § 6, 7-11-1973) 
Sec. 29-22. - Finance director, duties. 
    The finance director is hereby designated the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees as authorized herein and of the appropriated funds for the employer's contributions as provided in section 29-20 hereof. Also, the finance director is hereby designated the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining records for the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 73-16, § 7, 7-11-1973) 
Chapter 30 - PERSONNEL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 30-1. - Discriminatory personnel practices prohibited. 
(a)  Purpose. The general purpose of this section is to secure for all city employees freedom from discrimination because of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, marital status, political affiliation or disability (hereinafter referred to as "discriminatory classification") in connection with employment with the city. 
(b)  Definitions: 
    Age means being at least twenty-one (21) years of age. 
    Discriminatory classification means an unfounded classification on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, marital status, political affiliation or disability. 
    Discriminatory practice means a practice designated as found under the terms of this section. 
    Employee means any individual employed by, or seeking employment from, the city. 
    Disabled [individual] means any person who has: 
(1)  A physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one (1) or more of such person's major life activities; 
(2)  A record of such an impairment; or 
(3)  Is regarded as having such an impairment. 
A disabled individual is "qualified," with respect to employment, if he or she can perform the substantial functions of the job in question with reasonable accommodation. [For purposes of defining "disabled individual"] "major life activities" means functions such as caring for one's self, performing manual tasks, walking, seeing, hearing, speaking, breathing, learning and working; and "Substantially limited" means likely to experience difficulty in securing, retaining or advancing in employment because of a disability. 
    Marital status means the state of being unmarried, married, or separated, as defined by state law. The term "unmarried" includes people who are single, divorced, or widowed. 
    National origin includes the national origin of an ancestor. 
    Political affiliation means belonging to or endorsing any political party which does not espouse the overthrow of the government of the United States by force. 
(c)  Discriminatory practices enumerated. It is a discriminatory practice if any department of the city is found by the city manager or the civil service board to: 
(1)  Fail or refuse to hire, to discharge, or otherwise discriminate against an individual, with respect to compensation or the terms, conditions, or privileges of employment, because of a discriminatory classification; or, 
(2)  Limit, segregate or classify an employee in a way which would deprive or tend to deprive an individual of employment opportunities or otherwise adversely affect the status of an employee because of a discriminatory classification. 
(d)  Exemption from prohibition and nondiscriminatory practice. It is not a discriminatory practice for the city to classify or refer for employment or training, to admit or employ an individual on the basis of religion, sex, national origin, age, marital status, political affiliation, or absence of disability where the above are bona fide occupational qualifications as determined by the city manager and certified to the civil service board in accordance with the civil service rules. 
    No personnel action, including that of hiring, promotion, demotion, termination, discipline or loss of any benefits by any employee, applicant or prospective employee, shall be deemed discriminatory unless found to be so by either the city manager, or, if appealed under this section, by the civil service board. The actions of the city manager and the civil service board, if appealed, shall be final and binding. 
(e)  Enforcement: 
(1)  Any employee, former employee or individual seeking employment with the city who claims to have been discriminated against, as defined by this section, shall have the rights as provided in this section. The rights provided herein whether exercised or not shall be exclusive of any other administrative proceedings as provided by any other political subdivision of the state as defined by Florida Statutes, section 1.01. 
(2)  Said aggrieved individual shall be present and shall have the right to have present any individual or individuals which he or she alleges has violated this section to his or her detriment. 
(3)  The city manager shall obtain all pertinent documents and shall have the power to secure the presence of any and all employees or other individuals necessary for a full investigation of this matter. 
(4)  The city manager, after considering all relevant facts as demonstrated by documents and informal testimony, shall within ten (10) days make his findings as to whether the practice alleged is discriminatory under this section. 
(5)  If the city manager finds a discriminatory practice, as defined by this section, he shall have the power to: 
a.  Discipline any employee of the city involved in a discriminatory practice; 
b.  Reinstate with or without pay; 
c.  Withdraw any reprimand to an employee; 
d.  Provide that any employee/applicant discriminated against shall be first hired from any eligibility list for any funded position wherein he or she was discriminated against for either hire or promotion. 
e.  Order the immediate end to any discriminatory practice prohibited in this section. 
(f)  Appeal. Any affected individual dissatisfied with the findings and enforcement of the city manager regarding discriminatory practices under this section shall have the exclusive right to appeal to the civil service board pursuant to subsections 30-27(a), (c) and (d). The civil service board shall have the same powers as provided to the city manager in subsection (e)(5)a through e herein. The rights provided herein whether exercised or not shall be exclusive of any other administrative proceedings as provided by any other political subdivision of the state as defined by Florida Statutes, section 1.01. 
(g)  Provisions not restrictive as to power of city manager. This section shall not in any way be deemed to constrict the power of the city manager but shall be interpreted to confirm the power of the city manager to investigate any and all discriminatory practices as alleged hereunder. 
(h)  Civil service code to prevail where provisions conflict. Should there be any conflict between this section and the civil service code of the city as codified in article II of this chapter, this section shall prevail. 
(i)  County ordinance not applicable. The intent of this section is to retain internal control of investigation and enforcement of any alleged discriminatory practices within the city. This section shall be deemed to conflict with Broward County Ordinance No. 78-29, and said county ordinance shall have no force and effect over the city or any discriminatory practice alleged against same. 
(j)  Federal and state law applicable. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to supersede any federal or state statute or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 79-4, § 1, 1-3-1979; Ord. No. 84-17, §§ 1, 2, 5-16-1984; Ord. 98-2, § 1, 1-21-1998) 
Sec. 30-2. - Harassment prohibited. 
(a)  Policy as to harassment. It shall be the policy of the City of Margate that no employee, officer, or individual shall be subjected to harassment by any other employee, officer, or individual under the control or employ of the City of Margate. Harassment shall be defined as conduct based upon race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, marital status, political affiliation, or disability or conduct precipitated by one's race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, marital status, political affiliation, or disability, that has the effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating hostile or offensive working environment, and thus adversely affects the terms, conditions or privileges of employment of an individual. 
(b)  Procedure. Should any employee believe that he/she is being subjected to harassment as defined above, then said employee shall have the right to inform the office of the city manager of said belief. All communications regarding the reporting or belief that an individual or individuals have been harassed shall be kept confidential except to the extent necessary to conduct an investigation as provided in this section. 
    An employee who believes that he/she is being subjected to harassment, as defined herein, shall not be required to process any complaints or grievance through the chain of command or to immediate supervisors or department head. 
    The office of city manager shall conduct an investigation and have all powers as provided within section 30-1, subsections (e) through (h) of the City Code of the City of Margate. 
(Ord. No. 86-23, § 1, 11-5-1986; Ord. No. 98-2, § 2, 1-21-1998) 
Sec. 30-3. - Working hours of department heads above and below regular working hours. 
(a)  Overtime pay, compensatory time not available. Department heads of the city shall not receive overtime pay nor formal compensatory time for any amount of time worked over and above regular working hours. 
(b)  Discretionary time off during regular working hours. Time off for any department head during regular working hours shall be at the discretion of the city manager. 
(1)  Time off granted at the discretion of the city manager shall be over and above not related to formal sick time or formal vacation time accrued by any department head. 
(2)  The city manager shall keep records and inform the city commission of any time off during regular working hours which is granted to any department head other than formal sick or formal vacation time. 
(c)  Nonliability for overtime pay to terminated department head. Upon termination of a department head for whatever reason, voluntary or involuntary, said department head shall not be entitled to compensation for any time worked over and above regular working hours. 
(Ord. No. 78-32, § 1, 9-20-1978; Ord. No. 80-75, § 1, 12-17-1980) 
Sec. 30-4. - Salary and benefits for nonbargaining unit employees of the City of Margate. 
(a)  The salary and benefits of all employees of the City of Margate, not a part of any bargaining unit as recognized by the Public Employees Relations Commission of the State of Florida, shall be recommended to the city commission of the city on an annual basis by the city manager. 
(b)  Any nonbargaining unit employee of the city, within thirty (30) days of the city manager's recommendation of salaries and benefits to the city commission, may appeal directly to the city commission for adjustment as to same. No nonbargaining unit employee of the city may appeal or petition the city commission for adjustment to his salary or benefits beyond thirty (30) days of the city manager's original recommendation. 
(c)  The above shall not preclude the city manager from recommending salary and benefit adjustments throughout the year on his own initiative. 
(d)  All salaries and benefits of the city's nonbargaining unit employees shall be set by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 81-34, § 1, 5-20-1981) 
Secs. 30-5-30-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CIVIL SERVICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1977-10, §§ A-C, adopted July 6, 1977, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Art. I of a new Ch. 4, §§ 4-1-4-43. Since the Code already contained a Ch. 4 pertaining to different subject matter, the provisions of said ordinance have been codified herein at the editor's discretion as Art. II of a new Ch. 30, §§ 30-1-30-30, 30-39-30-54, and 30-61-30-79; the order of certain sections has been changed for purposes of classification and to facilitate inclusion of future material in the Code. 
Charter reference- Civil service system, § 7.01 et seq. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; officers and employees generally, § 2-41 et seq.; pensions, Ch. 29. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 30-21. - Civil service code designated; repeal of former rules, ordinances and regulations; distribution. 
    This article constitutes the civil service code of the City of Margate. All prior rules, ordinances, regulations and publications relative to the Margate civil service system are hereby rescinded. Each civil service employee will receive a copy of this article. 
(Ord. No. 77-10, § C, 7-6-1977) 
Sec. 30-22. - Merit principle adopted; declaration of intent. 
    There is hereby created a civil service system for the City of Margate. Employment in the city government will be based on merit and fitness, free from personal and political considerations. Just and equitable incentives and conditions of employment will be established and maintained to promote efficiency and economy in the operation of city government. Positions having similar duties and responsibilities will be classified and compensated on a uniform basis. Appointments, promotions and other actions requiring the application of the merit principle will be made according to merit and fitness, to be ascertained by competitive examinations. High morals will be maintained by fair administration, and tenure of the employees shall be subject to good behavior and satisfactory performance of work. 
(Ord. No. 77-10, § C, 7-6-1977) 
Sec. 30-23. - Covered personnel. 
(a)  All persons regularly employed by the city, except as hereinafter provided, will be construed to come within the provisions of the civil service of the city. 
(b)  The following positions shall not be deemed a part of the civil service of the city and no civil service ordinances nor rules governing the following positions shall apply: elected officials or persons appointed to fill vacancies in elected offices; the city manager; the city attorney; the city clerk; any employee directly responsible to the city manager, city attorney, or city clerk; directors of departments; the deputy city clerk, any employee of the city whose salary and benefits are completely funded by the community redevelopment agency; temporary employees; part-time employees; all employees of any independent contractors or separately funded programs of the city other than the general fund and enterprise fund. Excluded employees shall include employees of the Northwest Focal Point Senior Center District, and employees of the Alzheimer's Family Center. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision contained in this directive regarding appointments and employment, all other permanent employees of the city will be included hereunder. 
(d)  All permanent civil service employees, employed by the city upon the effective date of this regulation and having passed a qualifying examination and/or being certified by the civil service board as previously existing pursuant to ordinance, will retain the grade, title and seniority held at the effective date of this directive. It will not be necessary for said employees to be reappointed or to serve a probationary period. 
(e)  All employees of the department of municipal utilities will retain their present grade and title and seniority held at the effective date of the utilities becoming a department of the city government. It will not be necessary for said employees to be examined or reexamined, to be reappointed, or to serve a probationary period. Said municipal utilities department employees shall be subject to the same probationary requirement as other civil service employees. 
(f)  All employees will be employed, retained in employment and advanced to higher grades on merit and fitness only, except as hereinafter provided. Competitive examinations will be used to determine merit and fitness for initial employment and promotion. 
(g)  An employee who was employed in any city position that had civil service status but who left civil service status to fill a position that is exempted under the Margate Civil Service subsequent to May 1, 2012, shall not have the right to automatically return to a her/his previously held civil service status position, or its equivalent position. 
(Ord. No. 77-10, § C, 7-6-1977; Ord. No. 88-37, § 1, 12-21-1988; Ord. No. 96-21, § 2, 11-20-1996; Ord. No. 2003-03, § 1, 5-21-2003; Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 12-12-2007; Ord. No. 2010-18, § 1, 12-8-2010; Ord. No. 2011-9, § 1, 7-13-2011; Ord. No. 2012-4, § 1, 4-18-2012) 
Sec. 30-23.5. - Election and appointment of civil service board members. 
(a)  There shall be an election on February 19, 2010, and for every two (2) years thereafter, for the purpose of having all employees classified in the civil service system of the city elect two (2) members to the civil service board of the city. One (1) member to be elected to the civil service board shall be an employee of the classified civil service of the city and one (1) member need not be an employee of the city. 
(b)  The election shall be held between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. in the city clerk's office at city hall at 5790 Margate Boulevard. That said election shall be held and supervised by the city clerk or her designee. 
(c)  Any civil service employee may nominate a person to appear on the ballot for either position on the civil service board. A nomination shall specifically state which position the nomination is for; either 
(1)  The position open only to classified civil service employees, or 
(2)  The position open to any individual. 
(d)  The persons nominated to appear on the ballot must indicate his or her willingness to serve in writing to the city clerk's office. Failure to indicate a willingness to serve by written instrument shall be indicative of the party declining to serve and therefore the party's name will not appear on the ballot. No specific form is established for the written instrument. It may be in any form, typewritten, printed or written and should only indicate the intention of the party. 
(e)  Ballots shall be typed and prepared by the city clerk's office for the election. All parties indicating their willingness to serve shall have their names appear on the ballot. Sample ballots marked as such shall be posted a various locations throughout city hall. The ballots shall be prepared five (5) working days prior to the date set for election. Thereafter no additional names may be added to the ballot, but the ballot will provide one (1) space for a "write-in candidate." 
(f)  The individual receiving the most votes in each race (1-Open for civil service employees only; 2-Open to any person) for election to the civil service board shall be elected to the civil service board of the city in accordance with the City Charter. 
(g)  In the event of a tie between two (2) people or more for the highest number of votes in either race there shall be a runoff election between those two (2) people (or more as the case may be for either race). The tie or runoff election shall be held in accordance with these rules within ten (10) days from the date of initial election. 
(h)  The city clerk or her designee shall have each party filing a ballot sign a roster for the sole purpose of avoiding allegations or charges that any person may have voted twice. Each party desiring to vote shall sign the roster. Ballots need not be signed but may not be taken out of the city clerk's office once delivered to the party voting. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11, § 1, 9-3-2008) 
Sec. 30-24. - Selection of officers and organization of civil service board. 
(a)  The civil service board shall elect, by majority vote, a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary/chief examiner. Any vacancy occurring for any reason shall be filled in a similar manner. 
(b)  The chairman shall preside at board meetings and will represent the board at meetings with the city commission, the city manager, and city, county and state officials. If he is not available, the vice-chairman will represent the board at these meetings. All expenses shall be reimbursed subject to availability of city funds. The secretary/chief examiner is responsible for the administration of the civil service examinations and publication of the resulting eligibility lists as directed by the board. In the absence of a secretary, the secretary/chief examiner will keep the minutes of board meetings. 
(Ord. No. 77-10, § C, 7-6-1977) 
Sec. 30-25. - Date and time of meetings of civil service board. 
(a)  Regular civil service board meetings will be held at such time and date as designated by said board, not less than once monthly, except during the months of July, August and December. The meetings will be held in the municipal building and will be open to the public. 
(b)  Special meetings may be called by the chairman or by written petition of three (3) members of the civil service board directed to the chairman. 
(c)  Not less than three (3) members shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 77-10, § C, 7-6-1977) 
Sec. 30-26. - Duties and responsibilities of civil service board and chief examiner. 
(a)  Civil service board. The duties and responsibilities of the civil service board are to: 
(1)  Keep personnel records and files. 
(2)  Hold hearings in accordance with the city charter and the civil service code. 
(3)  Keep the city charter and civil service code current by making timely and appropriate recommendations to the city commission. 
(4)  Act as an advisory board to the city manager, the city commission and city employees. 
(b)  Chief examiner. The chief examiner of the civil service board shall be responsible to hold competitive civil service examinations and supply names of eligibles for employment under the civil service code to the civil service board. 
(Ord. No. 77-10, § C, 7-6-1977; Ord. No. 79-32, § 1, 8-1-1979; Ord. No. 79-36, § 1, 9-5-1979) 
Sec. 30-27. - Investigation of complaints and irregularities in civil service matters. 
(a)  The civil service board shall investigate all complaints and irregularities concerning civil service matters. 
(b)  In all matters being investigated other than those of a disciplinary action (disciplinary matters to be provided for in sections 30-61 through 30-66), but where same specifically impact a civil service employee, prospective employee or group of civil service employees, said investigation shall commence no later than: 
(1)  Thirty (30) days from the date in which same could have reasonably known of the controversy, action or the matter which investigation is requested, or, 
(2)  If a subject matter proposed to be investigated concerns any matter covered by a collective bargaining agreement between the City of Margate and any bargaining unit, the date in which a grievance must be brought to the first step of the grievance procedure of any collective bargaining agreement involved; 
whichever is a shorter period of time as to subsections (b)(1) and (2) above. 
(c)  The procedure utilized shall be informal, and sworn testimony need not be taken unless either the administration, the civil service board or any other affected party wishes a formal procedure to commence. 
(d)  If any party requests a formal procedure to commence, then the party requesting the formal procedure, if same is other than the administration or the civil service board, shall present its case first with rebuttal to the administration. However, if either the administration or the civil service board requests a formal procedure, then the administration shall present its evidence first. In all other respects, all formal procedures under this section shall conform to those provided in sections 30-63 through 30-65. 
(e)  The decision of the civil service board shall be final. 
(f)  Any member of the civil service board who provides testimony regarding disputed facts during an investigation pursuant to this section, or section 30-63 shall not be considered a member of the civil service board for purposes of voting to determine the decision of the civil service board regarding the investigation where the disputed facts are elicited. 
(Ord. No. 77-10, § C, 7-6-1977; Ord. No. 84-4, § 1, 1-18-1984; Ord. No. 2011-3, § 1, 2-16-2011) 
Sec. 30-28. - Job classifications; designation and review thereof. 
(a)  The city manager will designate job classifications, job descriptions and titles of positions in the various departments of the city, based upon the duties and requirements of the positions, and certify them to the civil service board. All employees passing the qualifying examinations, as hereinafter provided, will be retained in employment according to their classification designation. However, such classification will not prevent an employee from performing work in any other classification at the employee's regular rate of pay, when temporarily assigned that work by proper authority. A temporary assignment will not exceed six (6) months. Thirty (30) days prior to the expiration of the temporary assignment, the department head must notify the civil service board and the city manager of the temporary assignment. 
(b)  The civil service board will from time to time review positions to ascertain comparability of grade and position and make appropriate recommendation to the city manager and the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 77-10, § C, 7-6-1977) 
Sec. 30-29. - Manpower determination; reduction in number of employees of a grade or rank. 
    In the event of a reduction of a number of employees in any grade or rank, the employees will be retained in that grade or rank according to seniority, and the employee thus reduced to a lower grade or rank will retain his salary if it falls within the salary range of the lower grade. If the employee's salary does not fall within the salary range of the lower grade, his salary will then be decreased to the top step of the lower grade position. In the event the higher grade or rank is re-established, the employee will be first to succeed to said higher grade or rank, according to seniority, without further examination or a probationary period. An employee who is laid off or placed on inactive status will be placed on a preferred list, the rank, order of which is determined by seniority. The list will remain current for two (2) years and whenever a vacancy occurs in that category, reappointment will be effected from this list. 
(Ord. No. 77-10, § C, 7-6-1977) 
Cross reference- Similar provisions, § 30-70. 
Sec. 30-30. - Maintenance of roster of employees. 
    The civil service board will receive an official roster of all employees, listing name, address, date of appointment, change of status and pay data from the time an employee enters city service until he separates. Annually, immediately after the adoption of the budget, department heads will submit a table of organization to the civil service board and the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 77-10, § C, 7-6-1977) 
Sec. 30-31. - Preference points for veterans. 
    Veterans preference points shall be awarded in compliance with F.S. Ch. 295. 
( Ord. No. 2013-9, § 1, 9-18-2013 ) 
Sec. 30-32. - Appointments and promotions probationary. 
(a)  All initial appointees, in-house appointees, and promoted individuals shall serve a twelve-month probationary period, except for police officers, who shall serve eighteen (18) months. 
(b)  Initially employed probationary employees who are terminated or in-house appointees, and promoted probationary employees who are returned to their former rank or position prior to completion of their probationary period shall have no right to statement of cause nor reasons for same, nor to a hearing, nor appeal of same. 
(c)  As an alternative to termination or return to former rank or position before the completion of a probationary period, an employee may, with his/her consent, and at the sole discretion of the administration, have his/her probationary period extended for up to an additional six-month period. Employment pursuant to an extended probationary period shall be governed by subsection (b) above. 
( Ord. No. 2013-9, § 1, 9-18-2013 ) 
Sec. 30-33. - Temporary appointment. 
    A temporary appointment for a period not exceeding six (6) months may be made from the existing eligibility list upon recommendation of the department director to the city manager. In the event no eligible applicant accepts this appointment, appointment may be made at large. This appointment will not affect the candidate's standing on the eligibility list. 
( Ord. No. 2013-9, § 1, 9-18-2013 ) 
Sec. 30-34. - Performance evaluations. 
(a)  Employees will receive annual performance evaluations. The performance evaluations must be prepared by the immediate supervisor, evaluating the accomplishments, work habits, conduct, strong points and weaknesses of the employee. The performance evaluation must be discussed with the employee, who will sign and date it. This evaluation will be reviewed through the department's applicable chain of command, and his/her comments added. The completed performance evaluation shall be included in the employee's official personnel folder. 
(b)  An unsatisfactory efficiency rating will be brought to the attention of the city manager prior to transmitting the same to the human resources department. 
(c)  Whenever necessary, a special efficiency rating may be rendered. 
( Ord. No. 2013-9, § 1, 9-18-2013 ) 
Secs. 30-35-30-38. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INITIAL APPOINTMENT PROCEDURES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Sec. 2 of Ord. No. 2013-9 , adopted Sept. 28, 2013, amended §§ 30-39-30-56 in their entirety to read as herein set out. See Code Comparative Table for legislative history. 

Sec. 30-39. - Hiring policy. 
(1)  Policy. When a position becomes vacant or upon the establishment of a new budgeted position, the appropriate supervisor or department director shall notify the human resources department. The human resources department shall seek the most qualified applicants to fill vacancies for all job classifications, and shall establish a minimum level of performance standards of acceptance for employment, with the approval of the city manager. All elements of the selection process shall be job related, and shall be in accordance with applicable laws and with the City of Margate Code of Ordinances. The human resources department shall create the job posting for each budgeted vacancy which shall include the position title, starting salary, open and closing date for receipt of applications, minimum experience and training required, and ADA requirements. 
    Positions shall be posted on various City of Margate bulletin boards, the city's website, and other methods as appropriate for the position. Open positions shall be posted for two (2) calendar weeks; however, extensions may be made with the approval of the human resources director. Positions may also be posted for internal applicants only, upon the request of the department director and the approval of the human resources director, and may be posted for a shorter time period. 
    Submission of a resumé shall not be considered for open positions, and shall be returned to the applicant. In order to be considered for open positions, a City of Margate employment application form must be completed. 
(2)  Procedure. A separate application is required for each open position. Resumés attached to applications shall be reviewed for clarification purposes only. Applications shall be considered inactive once the open position is filled. Applications shall be retained on file for the required retention period. 
    The human resources department shall make all job offers with the approval of the city manager. All inquiries regarding employment opportunities shall be referred to the human resources department. 
    In compliance with the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1985, the City of Margate shall hire only persons lawfully authorized to work in the United States. 
    Applicants with disabilities who require accommodation within the application or interview process should direct requests in advance to the human resources department. 
(3)  Recruitment process. Applications shall be reviewed by the human resources department for the minimum qualifications for the position creating a matrix of all candidates and qualifications. Based on factors considered as above and beyond the minimum job requirements, applicants shall be assigned points on a criteria sheet, and be identified in ranking order on a spreadsheet, listing most to least qualified for the position. Those applicants determined to be in the top group of meeting the requirements of the position shall be forwarded to the appropriate department/ division for review. From this group, the department shall recommend a short list of candidates for interviews. 
    Applicants may be allowed to correct errors and deficiencies in the application prior to the oral interview. Errors, omissions, and deficiencies not corrected before the interview may disqualify the applicant from the selection process. Applicants shall be deemed not eligible for the following reasons: 
(a)  If the application was not received on or before the closing date established; 
(b)  If the applicant does not possess the minimum requirements of the position; 
(c)  If the applicant falsified or failed to complete or include information on the application; 
(d)  If the applicant was convicted of a charge that is related to the employment sought, they shall be considered on an individual case-by-case basis considering the position involved, the nature and gravity of the offense, conduct, and time since conviction; 
(e)  If the applicant was previously employed by the City of Margate and was dismissed or resigned not in good standing and is not currently eligible for re-hire by the city; 
(f)  Other reasons deemed sufficient by the human resources director and city manager. 
    An applicant who has been disqualified shall be given the reason(s) for same in writing, and be entitled to request an appeal to the human resources director in writing within seven (7) calendar days after notification of such disqualification. Applicants may, based on the decision of the human resources director and the department director, be required to take and successfully pass written, practical, or other types of examinations at any point in the hiring process. For any such examinations that are scored on a point basis, candidates must attain an examination score of not less than seventy (70) per cent in order to pass the examination and proceed to the next step in the hiring process. 
(4)  Interview process. Interviews of applicants for employment shall be closed to the public unless otherwise required by law. Where the interview process is deemed a public meeting by law, the public will be admitted in an observer status only and shall not participate in the interview. 
    A set of interview questions and exercises shall be developed by the department, with human resources' assistance if necessary, and approval, and distributed to the interview panel. 
    Questions shall be job-related pertaining to the relevant knowledge, skills, and abilities required to perform the essential functions of the position. Actual job scenarios and problem solving provides the foundation for good questions. A database of position-specific questions shall be maintained and used as a guideline by human resources for future vacancies. 
    Interviews may be conducted by panel process which shall typically consist of one (1) to two (2) management or supervisory staff members and a representative from the human resources department. Generally, each panel member shall take turns asking questions. Each candidate shall be asked the same set of questions. Test scores from pre-employment examinations (if applicable) shall also be reviewed. Performance appraisal forms, disciplinary history, and attendance records for current employees shall also be reviewed. 
    Prospective employees shall be considered disqualified from continuing further in the process if they do not promptly present themselves at the time and place for the interview. Under no circumstances shall the interviewer ask about an applicant's age, race, creed, color, sex, religion, marital or family status, sexual orientation, political or religious opinions or affiliations, national origin, health, or disability status. 
    The human resources department shall arrange the interviews and provide each applicant with the necessary information pertaining to the open position, eligible benefit package, and hiring process. 
    The interview panel members shall determine if the applicant(s) are able to perform the essential functions of the job with or without accommodation. This is to be accomplished by providing a copy of the job description to the prospective applicant and may be pursued, if necessary and appropriate, through inquiries into the ability of an applicant to perform the essential job-related functions. Inquiries may not be made into an applicant's physical or mental condition, but may inquire in a general manner about the applicant's ability to perform essential functions of the position as appropriate 
    At the conclusion of the interviews, the interview panel members shall collaboratively discuss applicants and determine the top applicant. The top applicant shall be recommended for hire to the city manager, who has the authority to approve or disapprove of the hire. After approval, the top applicant will move to the next step of the hiring process. 
    Interview questions and notes shall be sent to the human resources department for retention. 
    Applicants shall be hired at a salary which is within the established salary range of the position. Normally, a new employee is hired at the minimum of the pay range. Prior approval of the director of human resources and the city manager shall be required for external applicants if the starting salary exceeds the minimum of the pay range, and shall not exceed the midpoint of the salary range. 
    If a position becomes vacant and a previously announced position with the same job classification had been previously announced within six (6) months of the current vacancy, the human resources director may request to fill the position from the referrals of the previously announced position. Utilizing the referrals from previously announced positions, other candidates from the prior interview process shall be considered. 
(5)  Hiring process. An Employment Action Form (EAF) must be completed and signed before a conditional offer of employment shall be made. Human resources shall notify applicants, make conditional offers of employment, begin the required background search, and schedule the pre-employment physical and drug testing. A release form signed by the applicant must be obtained prior to any background search. The human resources department shall coordinate background investigations and shall include information regarding the applicant's character, work habits, performance, court records, criminal history, education, and experience, along with reasons for termination of past employment. Consistent with job requirements, additional information regarding driving records and credit reports may also be requested. A drug screen shall be required for all new hires to detect illegal drug use. A urinalysis sample shall be taken during the physical examination (if applicable) and sent to a designated laboratory for the appropriate testing. A record of the urinalysis test results shall be maintained in the human resources department's confidential medical file. Pre-employment physical examinations shall be required for all positions except those deemed temporary, seasonal recreational, or intern type positions as these positions are filled to assist in meeting temporary, unexpected operational and service demands. 
    An applicant may be disqualified from consideration for a position, or a conditional offer of employment withdrawn, where in the discretion of the human resources director it is determined that the applicant is ineligible to hold the position for which the applicant has applied. Reasons for determining ineligibility include, but are not limited to any of the following: 
(a)  Failure to meet technical qualifications for the position; 
(b)  Failure to provide all necessary information on the application for employment; 
(c)  Failure to provide all truthful information on the application for employment; 
(d)  Failure to pass drug screen; 
(e)  Failure to pass a medical examination and/or other appropriate and provided examinations; 
(f)  Determination by a licensed physician that the candidate cannot perform the essential functions of the position; 
(g)  Unsuitability based upon criminal background check (limited to records that are job related and consistent with business necessity); 
(h)  Unsuitability based upon general background or job history background checks. 
    An applicant who has been disqualified shall be given the reason(s) for same in writing, and be entitled to request an appeal to the human resources director in writing within seven (7) calendar days after notification of such disqualification. The human resources department shall coordinate and monitor all required new hire forms, including I-9 documents and payroll information, and shall schedule appropriate new hire and benefit orientation meetings. The human resources department shall notify in writing all candidates not selected for positions that the position applied for has been filled. All applications and related material received as a result of the recruitment and selection process including interview notes for all interviewed candidates shall be maintained in the human resources department. The information shall be maintained as required by law. 
( Ord. No. 2013-9, § 2, 9-18-2103 ) 
DIVISION 3. - PROCEDURES FOR PROMOTIONAL POSITIONS 

Sec. 30-40. - Examination announcements. 
    Promotional examinations shall be given only when required by an anticipated budget opening or vacancy, as determined in the discretion of the city manager. 
( Ord. No. 2013-9, § 2, 9-18-2103 ) 
Sec. 30-41. - Application for examination for position; information required, prerequisite to examination. 
(a)  Resumés, letters, applications, and related documentation shall be accepted only in response to an advertisement for a vacant promotional position.
