Sec. 33-69.53. - Operation of vehicle contrary to law prohibited. 
    Neither the owner nor any person employing or otherwise directing the driver of any vehicle shall require or knowingly permit the operation of such vehicle upon a street of this municipality in any manner contrary to law. 
(Ord. No. 78-10, § 1, 6-21-1978) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 78-10, § 1, adopted June 21, 1978, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as § 17-78; for purposes of classification the editor has designated said provisions as § 33-69.53. 
Sec. 33-70. - Parking violations, declared unlawful. 
(1)  Parking violations, declared unlawful. It is hereby declared to be unlawful and a violation of the city ordinances for any person to park in violation of any ordinance regulating parking within the city. This section shall apply to ordinances regulating parking on public or private property within the city. 
(2)  Penalty. Any person, firm or corporation violating any of the provisions of this article and the traffic code adopted shall be guilty of a violation of section 1-8 of this Code. 
(3)  Owner responsibility of parking violations. The owner of a vehicle is responsible and liable for payment of any parking violation. The owner of the vehicle shall not be responsible for a parking violation if the vehicle involved was, at the time, stolen, or in the care, custody or control of some person who did not have permission of the owner to use the vehicle. In such instances, the owner of the vehicle is required, within a reasonable time after notification of the parking violation, to furnish to the appropriate law enforcement authorities the name and address of the person or company who leased, rented or otherwise had the care, custody or control of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 77-19, § H, 9-7-1977; Ord. No. 79-8, § 1, 2-7-1979; Ord. No. 97-6, § 1, 3-5-1997; Ord. No. 98-7, § 1, 6-3-1998; Ord. No. 2001-16, § 2, 7-12-2001; Ord. No. 2011-2, § 2, 2-16-2011) 
Sec. 33-70.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-2, § 3, adopted Feb. 16, 2011, deleted [the former] § 17-70.1, which pertained to presumption in reference to illegal parking, operating, stopping, etc. and derived from Ord. No. 78-10, § 1, adopted June 21, 1978; Ord. No. 85-10, § 1, adopted April 3, 1985; and Ord. No. 97-7, § 1, adopted March 5, 1997. 
Sec. 33-71. - Forms and notices of parking citations. 
    The office of the chief of police of the city shall provide, in duplicate, suitable serially numbered forms for notifying alleged violators to answer to charges of violating parking ordinances. Such forms shall be issued and recorded by the police department of the city. 
(Ord. No. 78-10, § 1, 6-21-1978; Ord. No. 99-27, § 1, 11-3-1999) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 78-10, § 1, adopted June 21, 1978, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as § 17-80. The editor has redesignated said provisions as § 33-71, treating them as superseding the provisions of former § 17-71 which authorized establishment of a traffic parking ticket; said former section was derived from Ord. No. 77-19, § H, adopted Sept. 7, 1977. 
Sec. 33-72. - Notice and schedule of fines for illegally parked vehicles. 
(a)  Whenever any motor vehicle is found parked, stopped, or standing in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by ordinance of the municipality, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its tag number, and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle which may identify its user and shall conspicuously affix to such a vehicle a parking citation, on a form provided by the office of the chief of police, for the driver to answer the charge against him within the time prescribed herein. 
(b)  Such owner or operator receiving a notice as provided by the preceding section shall pay to the city as a penalty for, and in, satisfaction of such violation the sum of thirty-five dollars ($35.00). 
(c)  The penalty for parking within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant, parking within fifteen (15) feet of fire department connections, and parking within the fire lanes shall be the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(d)  The penalty for parking of a tractor-trailer, tractor portion of a tractor-trailer or trailer portion of a tractor-trailer in any prohibited area shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(e)  In the event the above applicable sum is not paid to the city within seven (7) working days of the issuance thereof, the penalty for such violation shall be the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) additional. 
(f)  The penalty for parking in a space reserved for disabled persons shall be the sum of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(g)  Any person who elects to appear before a county judge to present evidence regarding a parking citation shall be deemed to have waived his right to pay the civil penalty provisions as provided for in this section. The county judge, after hearing, shall make a determination as to whether a parking violation has been committed and shall impose a civil penalty of one hundred dollars ($100.00) (two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for parking in a disabled space), plus court costs. Any person who fails to pay the civil penalty within the time allowed by the court shall be deemed to have been convicted of a parking ticket violation, and the court shall take appropriate measures to enforce collection of the fine. 
(h)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit the prosecution of parking violations unrelated to the public rights-of-way and Chapter 316 of the Florida Statutes as a municipal violation, as provided in section 1-8 (a), (b), or (c) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 78-10, § 1, 6-21-1978; Ord. No. 79-3, § 1, 1-3-1979; Ord. No. 82-21, § 1, 5-19-1982; Ord. No. 83-31, § 1, 8-24-1983; Ord. No. 89-13, § 1, 7-12-1989; Ord. No. 92-13, § 1, 6-17-1992; Ord. No. 2000-7, § 2, 3-22-2000; Ord. No. 2000-23, § 1, 10-4-2000; Ord. No. 2008-18, § 1, 12-3-2008) 
Sec. 33-72.1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-2, § 4, adopted Feb. 16, 2011, deleted [the former] § 17-72.1, which pertained to penalty and derived from Ord. No. 77-19, § H, adopted Sept. 7, 1977; and Ord. No. 2000-7, § 3, adopted March 22, 2000. 
Sec. 33-73. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2011-2, § 5, adopted Feb. 16, 2011, deleted [the former] § 17-73, which pertained to display of prices of fuel for motorized vehicles and derived from Ord. No. 80-30, § 1, adopted April 23, 1980. 
Sec. 33-73.1. - Traffic infraction detectors. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. The purpose of this section is to specifically authorize the use of traffic infraction detectors, as permitted by general law as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives or July 1, 2013, whichever occurs later, within the city's jurisdictional limits. 
(b)  Use of traffic infraction detectors. The city hereby exercises its option under F.S. § 316.0083 as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives or July 1, 2013, whichever occurs later, to use traffic infraction detectors within its jurisdiction to enforce F.S. § 316.074(1) or § 316.075(1)(C), when a driver fails to stop at a traffic signal on streets and highways in the city's jurisdiction. The city may utilize traffic infraction detectors as a supplemental means of monitoring and assisting law enforcement personnel in the enforcement of compliance with laws related to traffic control signals as permitted and provided for by state law, which are designed to protect and improve the public health, safety, and welfare of the community and thereby reduce accidents, injuries and disruption of traffic associated with such violations. 
(c)  Implementation of general law. In accordance with the provisions of the Mark Wandall Traffic Safety Act as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives or July 1, 2013, whichever occurs later, the city authorizes the implementation of the provisions and requirements of F.S. §§ 316.003, 316.0083, 316.650, 318.15, 318.121, 318.18, and 320.03. Effective July 1, 2013, the city shall utilize its code compliance special magistrate as its local hearing officer, as defined by the amendments to F.S. §§ 313.003, 316.650, and 316.0083, in accordance with the provisions of the Mark Wandall Traffic Safety Act. The city commission shall provide for all procedures and rules necessary for implementation of this section, by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 2010-11, §§ 2, 3, 10-6-2010; Ord. No. 2013-3, § 2, 6-19-2013) 
ARTICLE VII. - PRECIOUS METALS 

Sec. 33-74. - Recording of sale of precious metals. 
(a)  Definitions: 
(1)  Merchant as used in this section shall mean any person who is the manager, proprietor or supervisor of any business establishment within the City of Margate wherein said business establishment makes purchases of precious metals from the general public. 
(2)  Precious metals as used in this section shall mean any metal composed of, in whole or in part, gold, silver or platinum. 
(3)  General public as used in this section shall mean any individual who is not regularly engaged in the buying or selling of precious metals as a licensed dealer. 
(b)  Records: 
(1)  All merchants within the city shall be required from the effective date of this section to keep a written record of all purchases of precious metals from the general public. That in the preparation of said record, and as a requirement of sale, the merchants shall obtain identification of the seller in order to properly ascertain his correct name and home address. 
(2)  The record of purchases herein required shall be kept on the business premises of the merchant three (3) years after the purchase and shall be made available to any law enforcement agency or officer upon request and shall include the following data: 
a.  The date of purchase. 
b.  A description of the item or items purchased. 
c.  The name and address of the seller. 
d.  The seller's signature. 
e.  The price paid for each item purchased. 
f.  The seller's driver's license number, if available. 
g.  A description of the source used to identify the name and home address of the seller. 
(Ord. No. 80-72, § 1, 12-10-1980) 
Cross reference- Jewelry dealer license fee, § 25-12(98). 
ARTICLE VIII. - NOISE CONTROL CODE 

Sec. 33-75. - Terminology and standards. 
    All terminology used in this article and not otherwise defined herein shall be defined in conformance with applicable publications of the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) or its successor body. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-76. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section. 
    A-weighted sound pressure level. The sound pressure level as measured on a sound level meter using the A-weighting network. The level so measured and read shall be designated db(A) to dBA. 
    Ambient noise level. The sound pressure level of the all encompassing noise associated with a given environment, being usually a composite of sounds from many sources. The A-weighted sound pressure level exceeded ninety (90) per cent of the time based on the one-hour period. 
    Continuous noise. A steady, fluctuating or impact noise which exists, essentially without interruption, for a period of one (1) hour or more. 
    Cyclically varying noise. Steady, fluctuating or impulsive noise which may or may not contain a pure tone, which varies in sound pressure level such that the same level is obtained repetitively at reasonably uniform intervals of time. 
    Decibel. A logarithmic (dimensionless) unit of measure often used in describing the amplitude of sound. Decibel is denoted as dB. 
    Device. Any mechanism which is intended to produce, or which actually produces noise when operated or handled. 
    Dynamic braking device. A device used, primarily on trucks, to convert the motor from an internal combustion engine to an air compressor for the purpose of vehicle braking without the use of wheel brakes. 
    Emergency vehicle. Emergency vehicle means a motor vehicle used in response to a public calamity or to protect persons or property from imminent danger. 
    Emergency work. Work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity, work to restore public utilities or work required to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger. 
    Fluctuating noise. The sound pressure level of a fluctuating noise varies more than six (6) dB(A) during the period of observation when measured with the slow meter characteristic of a sound level meter, and does not equal the previously existing ambient noise level more than once during the period of observation. 
    Impulsive noise. A noise containing excursions usually less than one second, of sound pressure level twenty (20) dB(A) or more, over the ambient sound pressure level, using the "fast" meter characteristic. 
    Level, day-night. A twenty-four-hour average of the A-weighted sound pressure level with the levels during the period 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. increased by ten (10) dB(A) before averaging. It is denoted L dn . 
    Level, ninetieth percentile. The A-weighted sound pressure level that is exceeded ninety (90) per cent of the time in any measurement period such as the level that is exceeded for fifty-four (54) minutes in one hour, and is denoted L 90 . 
    Level, ten percentile. The A-weighted sound pressure level that is exceeded ten (10) per cent of the time in any measurement period such as the level that is exceeded six (6) minutes in one hour, and is denoted L 10 . 
    Motor vehicle. Any vehicles, such as, but not limited to, passenger cars, trucks, truck-trailers, semitrailers, campers, motorcycles, minibikes, go-carts, amphibious craft on land, dune buggies or racing vehicles, which are propelled by mechanical power. 
    Motorboat. Any vehicle which is primarily operated on water or which does operate on water, such as boats, barges, amphibious craft or hover craft, and which is propelled by mechanical power. 
    Muffler. Any apparatus consisting of baffles, chambers, or acoustical absorbing material whose primary purpose is to transmit liquids or gases while causing a reduction in sound emission at one end. To qualify, such an apparatus must cause a reduction in sound pressure level of at least (x)dB(A) upon insertion into the system for which it is intended. 
    Noise. Any sound which is unwanted or which causes or tends to cause an adverse psychological or physiological effect on human beings. 
    Noise disturbance. Any sound which annoys, disturbs, or perturbs reasonable persons with normal sensitivities, or any sound which injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, hearing, peace or safety of other persons. 
    Period of observation. Period of observation is the time interval during which acoustical data and facts are obtained. All periods of observation made hereunder shall be determined with regard to the character of the noise being measured and the particular instrument used to make the measurement. It shall be ANSI S1.13-1971 of the American National Standards Institute. 
    Plainly audible noise. Any noise for which the information content of that noise is unambiguously communicated to the listener, such as, but not limited to, understandable spoken speech, comprehension of whether a voice is raised or normal, or comprehensible musical rhythms. 
    Powered model vehicles. Any powered vehicles, either airborne, waterborne or landborne, which are designed not to carry persons or property such as, but not limited to, model airplanes, boats, cars, rockets, and which are being propelled by mechanical means. 
    Property boundary. An imaginary line exterior to any enclosed structure, at the ground surface, which separates the real property owned by one person from that owned by another person, and its vertical extension. 
    Public right-of-way and public space. Any street, avenue, boulevard, highway, alley or public space which is dedicated to, owned or controlled by a public governmental entity. 
    Recreation vehicles. A piece of mechanized equipment for conveyance for off-road use. 
    Sound. A temporal and spatial oscillation in pressure, or other physical quantity, in a medium with internal forces that causes compression and rarefaction of that medium, and which propagates at finite speed to distance points. 
    Sound level meter. An instrument, including a microphone, amplifier, RMS detector and integrator, or time averager, output meter and weighting networks, that is sensitive to pressure fluctuation. The output meter reads sound pressure level when properly calibrated and the instrument is of Type 2 or better as specified in American National Standards Institute Publication S1.4-1971, or its successor publication. 
    Stationary noise source. Any device, fixed or movable, which is located or used on property other than a public right-of-way. 
    Steady noise. A sound pressure level which remains essentially constant during the period of observation, i.e., the fluctuations are too small to meet the criterion for fluctuating noise. 
    Vibration. A temporal and spatial oscillation of displacement, velocity or acceleration in a solid material. 
(Ord. No. 88-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-77. - Noise control officers. 
    The noise control program established by this code shall be administered by the police department of the City of Margate. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-78. - General prohibitions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make and/or continue, or cause to be made or continued, any excessive, unreasonable and/or unusually loud noise, or to create a noise disturbance within the limits of the City of Margate, as provided below. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-79. - Specific prohibitions. 
    The following acts are declared to be loud, disturbing and/or excessive noise in violation of this code: 
(a)  Horns and signaling devices. The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any motor vehicle on any public right-of-way, except as a danger warning signal or as provided in the Vehicle Code of the State of Florida, or the sounding of any such device for any unnecessary and unreasonable period of time, at any place. 
(b)  Radios, television sets and similar devices. Operating or permitting the use or operation of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, television, phonograph, drum or other device for the production or reproduction of sound, except as provided for in subsection (c) below, in such a manner as to cause noise disturbance so as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort of the neighborhood and vicinity thereof; operating any such device in such a manner as to be plainly audible across property boundaries or through partitions common to two (2) parties within a building or plainly audible at fifty (50) feet from such device when operated within a motor vehicle parked on a public right-of-way or on a public space, or within a motor boat. 
(c)  Exterior loudspeakers. Using or operating any mechanical device or loudspeaker in a fixed or movable position exterior to any building, or mounted upon any mechanical device or loudspeaker in a fixed or movable position exterior to any building, or mounted upon any motor vehicle such that the sound therefrom is plainly audible at or beyond the property boundary of the source, or on a public way except as provided for in section 33-81. 
(d)  Street sales. Selling anything by outcry within any area of the city zoned primarily for business or residential uses, except by permit. 
(e)  Animals. Owning, keeping, possessing or harboring any animal, bird or fowl which, by frequent or habitual howling, cause(s) a noise disturbance. The provisions of this subsection shall also apply to all private or public facilities, including any animal pounds, which hold or treat animals. It shall not be a violation of this subsection, however, for any animal, bird or fowl to give a sound of danger or warning in accordance with its nature or training. 
(f)  Loading operations. Loading, unloading, opening or otherwise handling boxes, crates, containers, garbage cans or otherwise similar objects between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day in such a manner so as to cause excessive and unnecessarily loud noises therefrom. 
(g)  Construction noise. Operating or causing to be operated any equipment used in commercial construction, repair, alteration or demolition work on buildings, structures, streets, alleys, or appurtenances thereto, in residential or commercial land use categories with sound-control devices less effective than those provided on the original equipment, or in violation of any regulation of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency. It shall further be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated the equipment aforementioned for the uses aforementioned between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day. Further, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate or cause to be operated said equipment on Sundays. Any person desiring to engage in the use of the aforementioned equipment for the aforementioned purposes beyond the hours and days of limitations aforementioned, based upon cases of necessity or the interest of public health, safety and convenience, may apply to the city manager for a special permit allowing same. Such permits, if granted, shall be limited to a period of up to thirty (30) days' duration, but may be renewed for additional periods of up to thirty (30) days if the emergency or need therefor continues. In the issuance of such permits, the city manager shall weigh all facts and circumstances and shall determine whether the reasons given for the necessity are valid and reasonable, whether the public health, safety and convenience will be protected or better served by granting the permit requested, and whether the manner and amount of loss or inconvenience to the party in interest imposes a significant hardship upon said party. 
(h)  Vehicle repairs or testing. Repairing, rebuilding, modifying or testing any motor vehicle, off-road vehicles or motorboat in or near a residential use district in such a manner as to cause noise disturbance or violate the provisions of section 33-82. 
(i)  Impulsive sources. The using of fireworks, explosives or other explosive devices without first obtaining a permit. 
(j)  Motor vehicle racing events. Operating or permitting the operation of any motor vehicle racing events at any place except an authorized track in a manner approved by the city manager to minimize noise disturbance. 
(k)  Powered model vehicles. Operating or permitting the operation of powered model vehicles between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following morning. Maximum sound pressure levels during the permitted period of operation shall conform to those set forth in Table I of section 33-82, and shall be measured at the property boundary of the source or at a distance of fifty (50) feet, if it is operated in a public place. 
(l)  Watercraft. Operating or causing the operation of any motorboat in any lake, river, stream or other waterway in such a manner as to violate the provisions of section 33-82. 
(m)  Lawn maintenance. Operating or causing to be operated any engine-powered lawn maintenance, lot clearing equipment or mowers powered other than by manual means between sunset and 7:00 a.m. in any residentially zoned or commercially zoned area of the city. 
    The city manager, or his designee, is authorized to grant an administrative waiver of the above prohibition to allow a golf course to operate engine-powered lawn maintenance equipment up to fifteen (15) minutes earlier than 7:00 a.m., based upon the following: 
(1)  A demonstration that the failure to grant the administrative waiver will have a deleterious effect on the operation of the golf course; 
(2)  The area which would be affected by the waiver is not so close to residences that it would defeat the purpose of this section; 
(3)  The city manager, or his designee, may grant the waiver with appropriate conditions necessary to ensure the intent of this section; 
(4)  The city manager, or his designee, may revoke a waiver where: 
a.  The operation of the golf course is not in compliance with the conditions imposed; 
b.  The operation of the golf course otherwise violates this section or any other ordinance; 
c.  There are changed conditions either as to the golf course or area adjoining same impacting the area of waiver; 
d.  It is determined by the city manager, or his designee, that the continuance of the waiver adversely impacts the health, safety, or welfare of the surrounding area or the city as a whole. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983; Ord. No. 84-21, § 1, 6-20-1984; Ord. No. 99-8, § 1, 5-5-1999; Ord. No. 2011-13, § 3, 9-21-2011; Ord. No. 2011-13, § 3, 9-21-2011) 
Sec. 33-80. - Emergency exception. 
    Noise caused in the performance of emergency work for the immediate safety, health or welfare of the community or individuals of the community, or to restore property to a safe condition following a public calamity shall not be subject to the provisions of this code. Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit ambulance or other emergency personnel to make excessive noise in the performance of their duties when such noise is clearly unnecessary. Ambulance, public works, public utilities and others who may be engaged in emergency work may test equipment which produces sound levels above those permitted by obtaining a permit from the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-81. - Exemption for time to comply. 
    Upon good cause shown by the owner of any noise source, the city manager shall have the power to grant an exemption from the provisions of this code in order to allow sufficient time for the installation of needed control equipment, facilities or modifications to achieve compliance. Provided, however, the aforementioned exemptions shall not be granted for a period of time to exceed fifteen (15) days from the date said exemption is granted, but such exemption may be renewed for an additional fifteen-day period if satisfactory progress towards compliance is shown. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-82. - Maximum noise level in use districts. 
(a)  Prohibited to exceed levels. It shall be unlawful within the use districts as indicated in Table I below for a sound or noise source to exceed the maximum noise levels as set forth in Table I as follows:

(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-83. - Maximum permissible noise levels of motor vehicles on public right-of-ways. 
    No person shall operate or permit to be operated a motor vehicle on a public right-of-way at any time under any condition of roadway grade, load, acceleration or deacceleration in such manner as to generate a sound level in excess of the limits established by Florida Statutes, Section 316.293(2). The measurement procedures for determining compliance with this section shall be as established by the Department of Pollution Control of the State of Florida in accordance with Florida Statutes, Section 316.293(3). 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-84. - Federal preemption. 
    At such time as the administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency establishes noise standards applicable to the operation of licensed interstate motor carriers pursuant to Section 18 of the Federal Noise Control Act of 1972 (Public Law 92-574), said standards and measurement techniques shall be incorporated herein by reference and the motor vehicle noise limits and measurement locations set forth in section 33-83 shall be superseded with respect to those classes of motor vehicle operators covered by said federal standards. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-85. - Recreational vehicles. 
    On or after ninety (90) days from the date of enactment of this code, no new recreational vehicle, as defined herein, shall be sold, rented or leased in the city for use in Margate unless such vehicle produces no more than a maximum sound level of eighty-two (82) decibels at fifty (50) feet from said vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-86. - Sound level measurement. 
    Sound level measurement shall be made with a sound level meter using the "A" weighting scale in accordance with those standards promulgated by the American National Standards Institute. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-87. - Land use-Residential use. 
    No new residential construction, either single- or multiple-family, shall be approved if the sound pressure level existing in the area of proposed construction exceeds sixty-five (65) dBA for more than twelve (12) hours in twenty-four (24) hours on a normal weekday at any point on the proposed site where habitation is to occur. For multistory buildings, the appropriate height shall be used. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-88. - Same-Commercial or industrial use. 
    No new commercial or industrial construction shall be approved unless it can be shown that the provisions of this code can be met for existing land use zoning. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-89. - Road construction. 
    No new road construction will be approved, whether locally funded or not, for residential areas, unless necessary noise control measures are taken to ensure that the sound pressure levels due to vehicles on the finished roadway do not exceed sixty-five (65) dB(A) more than twelve (12) hours in twenty-four (24) hours at all nearby existing residential construction on a normal weekday at all exterior points of the residences. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Sec. 33-90. - Undue hardship. 
    Applications for permission to hold a public event which may violate the provisions of this code shall be made to the city commission. Such permission, if granted, shall be valid only at the specific location, times, dates and upon the conditions as specified by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 83-34, § 2, 11-2-1983) 
Secs. 33-91-33-99. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - MISCELLANEOUS 

Sec. 33-100. - Individual pricing of retail items. 
(a)  Required. Except as specified hereinbelow, each item offered for retail sale by all businesses located within the City of Margate shall have the price of such individual item conspicuously marked thereon. 
(b)  Exemptions. Any retail business within the City of Margate equipped with an optical scanner(s) capable of reading the Universal Products Code may apply to the city commission for an exception to this section. In order to protect the consumers of Margate, the following criteria are established as the minimum business practice which must be placed into effect prior to the approval by the city commission: 
(1)  Conspicuously display the price of a product by means of a large, easy to read adhesive-backed price label containing bold numbers, which numbers shall measure not less than seven-eighths (7/8) of an inch in height, aligned and affixed beneath and to the left boundary of each applicable product display, or shelf molding below the product and plainly identifying the product to which the price applies. 
(2)  Adopt and maintain a written policy to consumers that the price charged to them for each product scanned at checkout will be not greater than that stated on the applicable price label, and making provision for the immediate reimbursement of any overcharge, such policy to be conspicuously displayed at each check-out counter and at each entranceway. 
    Note: A copy of the written policy to be placed into effect will be submitted with the letter requesting an exception to this section. 
(c)  Revocation of exception. Any retail business operating within the City of Margate that has been granted an exception to this section and where it has been shown that said retail business has violated this section five (5) times during any six (6) consecutive month period will automatically have the exception to this section revoked. This is in addition to any other civil penalties provided for within this section. Such retail business will not be able to reapply for an exception to this section for a six-month period following the suspension. Appeals by [from] revocation will be made to the city commission who will be the sole arbitrator as to whether such revocation shall continue or exception be continued. 
(d)  Penalties for violation. Each violation of this section shall be considered as a separate offense and shall be punishable pursuant to section 1-8 of the City Code. Further, the city attorney is hereby authorized to seek injunctive relief against continued or further violations of this section. 
(Ord. No. 84-35, § 1, 10-17-1984) 
Sec. 33-101. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 85-39, § 2, enacted Oct. 2, 1985, repealed the provisions formerly codified as § 17-101, [currently 33-101,] which derived from Ord. No. 85-25, § 2, adopted June 19, 1985, and contained miscellaneous provisions pertaining to travel agents and agencies. 
Sec. 33-102. - Unlawful connection to water system. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, corporation, partnership or other legal entity to connect, or cause to have connected, any water line, jumper, hose, or other device or conduit for water to a city-owned water line which is unmetered or which would have the effect of bypassing a city utility meter if water were to be used from said line, jumper, etc. 
(b)  It shall be a rebuttable presumption that any and all persons, corporations, partnerships or other legal entities which would benefit from the use of the water utilized from a connection, jumper, etc., as described in the preceding paragraph, shall be deemed the persons or entities which connected, or caused to be connected, the connection, jumper, etc., as described in paragraph (a) above. 
(c)  Any violation of this section shall be punishable pursuant to section 1-8 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 85-28, § 1, 7-2-1985) 
Cross reference- Water and sewers, Ch. 39. 
Sec. 33-103. - Maintenance standards for private swimming pools. 
    All swimming pools shall at all times be maintained so as not to constitute a sanitary nuisance. It shall be the duty and responsibility of every person owning, leasing or having an interest, legal or equitable, including but not limited to mortgage-holder, in any property situated in the city upon which is installed, erected or constructed a swimming pool, to maintain said swimming pool at all times in a sanitary condition. Dirt, algae, and scum shall be removed as often as necessary to maintain good sanitary conditions. All swimming pools shall be thoroughly cleansed at least once each week in a manner and by the use of such disinfectant agents or cleansing materials as may be required by the administration and the water in all such pools shall be completely circulated at least twice each week. 
(Ord. No. 86-18, § 1, 9-17-1986) 
Sec. 33-104. - Graffiti; writing on property without permission of owner prohibited. 
(a)  "Graffiti" shall be defined as any writing, painting, drawing, inscription, figure or mark of any type on any building, public or private, or any other property, real or personal, that has been made without the permission of the owner, tenant, or person in control of said property. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to inscribe, draw, or otherwise create graffiti on any real or personal property within the city. 
(c)  A parent or natural guardian of a minor convicted under this section shall be liable for any fine assessed by the court, in addition to the liability imposed by F.S. § 741.24, as amended. 
(d)  It shall be appropriate for the judge of any court to award restitution to any victim, public or private, which has, at its cost, removed graffiti from property, against any parent or natural guardian of a minor convicted under this section. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person or entity owning, occupying, or controlling any real or personal property to allow to exist on such property graffiti as defined in subsection (a) above. The owner, tenant, occupier or person in control of the real or personal property which is in violation of this section shall have forty-eight (48) hours in which to remove, paint over, or otherwise obliterate graffiti, as defined in subsection (a) above. 
(f)  Should graffiti as above described not be removed within forty-eight (48) hours of its existence on real or personal property, then the city shall cause a certified letter, return receipt requested, to be sent to all owners, tenants, occupiers, or persons in control of the real or personal property in which the graffiti exists. Said notice shall state that the owner, tenant, occupier or person in control of the real or personal property shall remove the described graffiti within five (5) days of the receipt of the notice given or to request a hearing with the city manager or his/her designee, which meeting shall take place within forty-eight (48) additional hours as below described. 
(g)  If the graffiti as above provided is not removed or a hearing is not requested, then, and in that event, the city shall have the right to remove, paint over or obliterate the above graffiti as defined herein. The cost of such removal shall be at the expense of owner, tenant, occupier, or person in control of the real or personal property in which the graffiti existed. Should the city not be paid within thirty (30) days of the work accomplished in removing graffiti, same shall constitute a lien against the property and be recorded in the public records of the county and shall accrue interest at the prevailing rate of interest. 
(h)  Where any owner, tenant, occupier or person in control of any real or [personal] property requests, within forty-eight (48) hours of the time in which they receive notice as above stated, an informal hearing before the city manager or his/her designee to demonstrate that the property they own or control does not have graffiti on it, or that such property will be free of graffiti within a reasonable time (not to exceed an additional forty-eight (48) hours) of the meeting with the city manager, the determination of the city manager or his/her designee shall be final. Should a determination of the city manager or his/her designee for removal of graffiti not be complied with within forty-eight (48) hours of his/her decision, the procedure as provided for in subparagraph (f) shall apply. 
(i)  The liens provided herein shall be prior to all other liens on such properties liened except for those for state, county, municipal or other governmental taxes. Upon an action for foreclosure, the city shall receive all costs including reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Ord. No. 88-18, § 1, 7-6-1988; Ord. No. 93-15, § 1, 7-7-1993; Ord. No. 2006-02, § 1, 4-19-2006) 
Sec. 33-105. - Possession of aerosol spray paint by minors prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen (18) to have in his or her possession any aerosol spray can containing any substance commonly known as paint or containing any other opaque liquid capable of being propelled by the aerosol can while on public property or upon private property without the consent of the owner of such private property. 
(b)  A parent or natural guardian of a minor convicted under this section shall be liable for any fine assessed by the court in addition to the liability imposed by F.S. § 741.24, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 88-18, § 1, 7-6-1988) 
Sec. 33-106. - Convenience store security. 
(a)  Generally. Each convenience store located within the city shall: 
(1)  Be equipped with the following security devices: 
a.  A silent alarm that notifies a private security agency that a robbery is taking place. 
b.  A security camera system capable of retrieving an image to assist in the identification and apprehension of a robber. 
c.  A drop safe or a cash-management device that provides minimum access to the facility's cash receipts. 
(2)  Provide lighted parking lot illuminated at an intensity of two (2) foot candles per square foot with a uniformity ratio of no more than five (5) to one (1) at eighteen (18) inches above the surface. 
(3)  Post a conspicuous sign in the convenience store entrance which states that the cash register contains fifty dollars ($50.00) or less. 
(4)  Maintain window signage so that there is a clear unobstructed view of the cash register and transaction area. 
(5)  Prohibit window tinting on the windows of the establishment if such tinting reduces exterior or interior viewing during the hours of operation to which this act is applicable. 
(6)  Install height markers at the entrance of the establishment which display height measures from the floor. 
(7)  Establish a cash-management policy to limit the amount of available cash on hand between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(b)  Training of Employees. No later than June 30, 1991, the owner or principal operator of a convenience store shall provide proper robbery deterrence and safety training to at least its employees who work between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. Any proposed program of training shall be submitted in writing to the attorney general of the State of Florida and shall be reviewed and approved pursuant to the standard provided for in Chapter 90-346, Section 6, of the laws of the State of Florida. 
(c)  Penalty for noncompliance. Any convenience store failing to comply with any of the standards or regulations provided in subsections (a) and (b) above shall receive written notice of said failure. Should any convenience store fail to comply ten (10) days after written notice has been received, then the owner or operator shall be fined as follows: 
(1)  First offense: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) civil penalty; 
(2)  Second offense: Two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) civil penalty; 
(3)  Third and subsequent offense: Five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) civil penalty. 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing, if it is determined that any owner or principal operator of a convenience store willfully and deliberately violates the requirements of subsections (a) and (b) as above-stated or deliberately fails to initially implement the requirements as above-provided, then the penalty for the same shall be a civil fine of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 90-12, § 2, 12-19-1990) 
Sec. 33-107. - Code compliance officers. 
(a)  Position authorized. The city administration is hereby authorized and empowered to create the position of code compliance officer of the city. 
(b)  Powers. Code compliance officers of the city shall be those individuals certified by the administration of the city that are empowered to civilly enforce the ordinances and Code of the City of Margate and Broward County, as provided by Chapter 162 of the Florida Statutes. 
(c)  Assignment to department. The code compliance officer shall work within the framework of such department as the city manager has determined to be in the best interests of the city. 
(d)  Qualifications. Qualifications shall be those as provided for by Florida Statute but should specifically include familiarity with the Code of the city in which they are to enforce the procedures of enforcement as set forth under Florida Statutes Section 162.21, knowledge of the city and its residents, and such law enforcement training as the administration deems necessary. 
(Ord. No. 91-28, § 2, 11-20-1991; Ord. No. 2001-07, § 1, 4-4-2001; Ord. No. 2002-01, § 1, 1-23-2002) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 91-28, § 2, adopted Nov. 20, 1991, amended the Code by adding a new section 17-106. Inasmuch as § 17-106 already existed in the Code, such provisions were codified as § 17-107, [currently 33-107]. 
Secs. 33-108-33-108.15. - Reserved.

No. 2009-05, § 1, adopted Feb. 18, 2009, from which the following sections derived: § 33-108.1, intent; § 33-108.02, use of image capture technologies; § 33-108.03, definitions; § 33-108.04, adherence to red light traffic control signals; § 33-108.05, violation; § 33-108.06, sixty-day notice; introductory period; § 33-108.07, review of recorded images; § 33-108.08, notice of infraction; violation; § 33-108.09, vehicle owner responsibilities; § 33-108.10, appeal to special magistrate; § 33-108.11, vehicle owner affidavit of nonresponsibility; § 33-108.12, penalties; § 33-108.13, administrative charges; § 33-108.14, collection of tines; and § 33-108.15, exceptions. 
Sec. 33-109. - Reserved. 
Sec. 33-110. - Combat Automobile Theft (CAT) Program. 
(a)  Definitions. [The following terms, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to herein, except where context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Administrative fee. Citizens Crime Watch shall charge a maximum fee of three dollars ($3.00) for enrollment in the program. 
    Consent form. A legally binding form designed by the police department and Citizens' Crime Watch in accordance with Florida Statutes, Section 316.008 to be signed by the owner of the vehicle enrolled in the CAT program. Once signed, the consent form will be kept on file with the Citizen's Crime Watch and serve as written authorization to stop the vehicle designated on the form between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
    Decal. An adhesive emblem designed by the city police department and Citizens' Crime Watch in accordance with the provisions of Florida Statutes, Section 316.008 for the purpose of posting in the lower left back window of a motor vehicle to indicate owner consent for a traffic stop in accordance with the requirements of the combat automobile theft (CAT) program. 
    Owner. The legally recorded holder of the title of a motor vehicle able to apply for a certificate of title or duplicate certificate of title or register or transfer title to a motor vehicle. 
    Vehicle. A conveyance meaning the description of a motor vehicle as defined in Florida Statutes, Section 316. 
(b)  Regulations. All persons enrolling a vehicle or vehicles in the city CAT program agree that all duly authorized law enforcement officers may stop the vehicle between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. and require the driver to produce proof of ownership of the vehicle. All persons enrolling in the CAT program shall comply with the following regulations: 
(1)  Complete a notarized consent form for all owners for each vehicle enrolled in the program to the Citizens' Crime Watch office. 
(2)  At the time of submission of the consent form, provide the Citizens' Crime Watch office with proof of ownership of each vehicle to be enrolled in the program, either certified title or registration certificate. 
(3)  At the time of submission of the consent form, provide the Citizens' Crime Watch office with personal identification either in the form of the driver's license or birth certificate. Only the certified owner(s) of a vehicle to be enrolled can enroll the vehicle into the program. 
(4)  At the time of enrollment, the decal must be immediately affixed to the lower left corner of the back window of the vehicle. 
(5)  Upon selling or otherwise transferring ownership of the vehicle, the seller shall remove the decal. 
(6)  Upon terminating participation in the program, the registered owner(s) shall remove the decal. 
(7)  Upon selling, transferring ownership of the vehicle, or upon terminating participation in the CAT program, the registered owner(s) shall notify the Citizens' Crime Watch office via the self-addressed postcard provided at the time of enrollment. 
(c)  Disclaimer of liability. No civil liability shall arise from the actions of a city law enforcement officer when stopping a vehicle with a yellow decal evidencing enrollment in the combat automobile theft program, provided that the stop is made in accordance with the program. 
(Ord. No. 92-28, § 1, 10-21-1992) 
Secs. 33-111-33-119. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - NEWSRACKS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, adopted Dec. 8, 2004, amended Art. X in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former Art. X derived from Ord. No. 95-24, § 2, adopted Dec. 6, 1995; and Ord. No. 2004-05, § 1, adopted June 2, 2004. 
In amending this article, Ord. No. 2004-19 created §§ 17-127 through 17-130. Inasmuch as said sections already existed as part of Art. XI, they have been redesignated as §§ 17-126.1 through 17-126.4, [currently 33-126.1 through 33-126.4,] at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 33-120. - Findings. 
    The city finds the uncontrolled placement and maintenance of newsracks in the city's public rights-of-way presents an inconvenience and danger to the public safety and welfare of persons using such rights-of-way, including pedestrians, children, the aged, persons entering and leaving vehicles and buildings, drivers, persons performing essential utility, traffic control and emergency services and persons with disabilities. Furthermore, the uncontrolled placement of newsracks has had a deleterious impact on the appearance of the public rights-of-way, significantly detracting from the aesthetic quality of the city. 
    The continued uncontrolled placement of newsracks is detrimental to the city's substantial efforts to beautify the city's public rights-of-way as part of programs to significantly improve the appearance of the community and enhance the quality of life of its residents. The city's streets and sidewalks have been immemorially held in trust for the entire public. Consistent with the First Amendment to the United States Constitution, the city has the authority to further its significant interests in aesthetics and public safety. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 12-8-2004) 
Sec. 33-121. - Intent. 
    The purpose of this article is to promote the public health, safety and welfare through the regulation of placement, type, appearance, servicing and ensuring of newsracks on public rights-of-way so as to: 
(1)  Provide for pedestrian and driving safety and convenience; 
(2)  Provide for the safety of the public and property during severe windstorm conditions; 
(3)  Provide reasonable access for the use and maintenance of poles, posts, traffic signs or signals, hydrants, mailboxes and access to locations used for public transportation purposes; 
(4)  Restrict unreasonable interference with the flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic, including ingress into or egress from any residence or place of business, or from the street to the sidewalk by persons exiting or entering parked or standing vehicles; 
(5)  Relocate and/or replace newsracks which result in drivers' sight line obstruction, a visual blight and/or excessive space allocation on the public rights-of-way, or which unreasonably detract from the aesthetics of store window displays, adjacent landscaping and other improvements, as well as to have abandoned newsracks removed; 
(6)  Reduce unnecessary exposure of the public to personal injury or property damage; 
(7)  Maintain and protect the value of surrounding properties; 
(8)  Treat all newspapers equally regardless of their size, content, circulation, or frequency of publication; 
(9)  Cooperate with newspaper distributors to preserve and maintain freedom of the press. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 12-8-2004) 
Sec. 33-122. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly indicates that a different meaning is intended: 
    City. The City of Margate, a Florida municipal corporation, as geographically described in the City Charter. 
    Compliance period. The compliance period shall mean the period of time specified in section 33-128 of this article after which nonconforming newsracks are subject to enforcement action. 
    Newsrack compartment. Each compartment within a newsrack designed to contain the newspapers or publications being distributed from that newsrack. 
    Newsracks. Any typed of unmanned device including any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser installed, used, or maintained for the display and sale of newspapers or other written periodicals, or for the vending or free distribution of newspapers or written periodicals. 
    Public rights-of-way. Any public street, highway, sidewalk, swale or alley. 
    Roadway. That portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel. 
    Sidewalk. Any surface provided for the exclusive use of pedestrians, on any public rights-of-way under the jurisdiction of the city. 
    Street. All that area dedicated to public use for public transportation purposes and shall include, but not be limited to, roadways, pathways, alleys and sidewalks. 
    Swale. That area between the sidewalks and the curb of any roadway, and where there is no sidewalk; that area between the edge of the roadway and property line adjacent thereto. "Swale" shall include any area within a street that is not open to vehicular travel. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 12-8-2004) 
Sec. 33-123. - Application and issuance of newsrack certificate of compliance. 
(a)  Issuing authority. The issuing authority and coordinator shall be the director of the department of environmental engineering services ("DEES"). The director of DEES shall oversee the various departments responsible for fairly coordinating and administering the physical placement of newsracks of the type and location herein specified, and upon compliance with the criteria set forth herein, the director of DEES shall be responsible for the issuance of the certificate of compliance. 
(b)  Applications. The applicant shall file with the director of DEES, a written application for the installation of a newsrack(s) in public rights-of-way which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone number of the applicant who is the owner and/or principal responsibly in charge of the newsrack(s). 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of a responsible person whom the city may notify or contact at any time concerning the applicant's newsrack(s). 
(3)  The applicant shall identify the location(s) and/or address(es) where the newsrack(s) will be located. Such information shall be in sufficient detail so as to allow the city to precisely locate the newsrack so as to ensure that the intended location of the newsrack containing the newsrack compartments satisfies the criteria and safety standards set forth in this article. 
(4)  Names of the newspapers or periodicals to be distributed by the applicant. 
(5)  Construction plans must be prepared by a Florida registered engineer according to the specifications in section 33-128. 
(6)  A step-by-step procedure for the newsrack application procedure is attached as exhibit "A". 
(c)  Issuance of certificate of compliance. Upon a finding by the director of DEES that the applicant is in compliance with the provisions of this article, a certificate of compliance shall be issued for installation by the newspaper distributor in accordance with the application and the provisions of this article. 
(d)  Denial of certificate of compliance. If a certificate of compliance for a newsrack location(s) applied for is denied, the applicant will be notified by certified mail of the specific cause of such denial. The notice of denial may suggest an alternative location(s). The applicant may reapply for a substitute alternative location(s) with no additional review fees. For the purposes of this article, a denial shall be based upon a determination by the director of DEES that the application has failed to comply with the standards, criteria and/or requirements of this article. 
(e)  Appeals. Any person aggrieved by any order, finding or determination taken under the provisions of this article other than a code enforcement action (hereinafter "appellant") may file an appeal with the code enforcement special master for the City of Margate. The appellant must affect the appeal within twenty-one (21) days after date of issuance of the order mailed to the appellant pursuant to this article. In order to effect the appeal, the appellant must deliver a letter of appeal, briefly stating the basis of the appeal, to the clerk to the special master. A hearing before the special master shall be scheduled on the appeal no later than forty (40) days following the receipt of the letter of appeal, unless the parties mutually agree to an extension. The appellant shall be given at least seven (7) days' written notice of the time and place of the hearing. The special master shall give the appellant a reasonable opportunity to be heard in order to show cause why the order, finding or determination is inconsistent with the requirements of this article. At the conclusion of the hearing the special master shall make a final and conclusive determination. The determination shall be reduced to writing and signed by the special master and filed in the office of the city clerk within fifteen (15) days of the hearing and a copy shall be sent to the appellant. The decision of the special master shall be effective when rendered. The decision may be appealed as provided by law. After removal of the newsracks, the owner shall again be given written notice. Upon failure of the owner, following such notice, to claim the newsrack and pay the expenses of removal and storage, except where an appeal of the city commission's decision has been filed, the newsrack shall be deemed unclaimed property in possession of the city and may be disposed of pursuant to law. 
(f)  Additional newsrack certificate(s) of compliance. If at any time after initial application for a certificate of compliance, a distributor wishes to install additional newsracks, then the above-cited application process is to be repeated in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 12-8-2004) 
Sec. 33-124. - Insurance, indemnification and hold harmless. 
(a)  Insurance. Prior to the issuance of a certificate of compliance, every publisher or distributor who places or maintains a newsrack on a public right-of-way, public sidewalk, street or swale in the city shall furnish to the director of DEES a current certificate of insurance on October 1 of each year. Reasonable evidence of equivalent self-insurance coverage may be substituted by the applicant for the above certificate of insurance, subject to the approval of the risk manager and city attorney. Such insurance shall be comprehensive general liability insurance on an occurrence basis with limits of liability not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and/or aggregate combined single limit, personal injury, bodily injury and property damage. Insurance under this section shall run continuously with the presence of the applicant's newsrack(s) in city rights-of-way, and any termination or lapse of such insurance shall be a violation of section 1-8 of the Margate Code. 
Coverage shall include the following extensions: (a) contractual liability; (b) products and completed operations; (c) independent contractor's coverage; (d) broad for general liability extensions or equivalent. 
The City of Margate shall be named as additional insured. 
Cancellation notice. Comprehensive general liability insurance as described above shall include an endorsement stating: "Sixty (60) days advance written notice of cancellation or non-renewal shall be sent to the City's Risk Manager, 5790 Margate Blvd., Margate, FL 33063." 
(b)  Indemnification/hold harmless. Every publisher or distributor who places or maintains a newsrack on a public right-of-way, public sidewalk, street or swale in the city shall execute and deliver a written agreement under which it agrees to indemnify, hold harmless and defend the city, its officers, agents and employees from any loss, liability, or damage, including expenses and costs, for bodily or personal injury, and for property damage sustained by any person as a result of the installation, use and/or maintenance of a newsrack within the city. This shall not be construed to affect in any way the city's rights, privileges, and immunities as set forth in F.S. § 768.28. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 12-8-2004) 
Sec. 33-125. - Fees. 
    There shall be a one-time application fee in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each applicant. There shall be an additional fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) per location, which must be renewed annually on October 1, along with the certificate of insurance (subsection 33-124(a)). Failed inspections are subject to a reinspection fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to defray administrative expenses related to this article. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 12-8-2004) 
Sec. 33-126. - Installation and maintenance. 
    Newsracks shall be placed and maintained in accordance with the following criteria: 
(1)  The exterior dimensions for newsracks shall be as follows: Each newsrack shall utilize rectangular pedestal(s) with dimensions eight (8) by six and one-half (61/2) inches with a height of nineteen (19) inches. Each newsrack shall have dimensions, excluding the pedestal and any slab, of fifty-five (55) inches in height and a depth (measured front to back) of sixteen (16) inches. Each newsrack compartment in a newsrack shall have width of twenty-four and one-eighth (24 1/8 ) inches as measured across the front of the newsrack compartment. Each newsrack shall contain no more than six (6) newsrack compartments. The total width of each newsrack shall not exceed seventy-two and three-quarter (723/4) inches, with a maximum of two (2) newsracks side by side. News racks shall be of a "K" style, "TK" style or free style, as depicted by Exhibit "B". 
(2)  Newsracks shall have a gloss finish coated per standard specifications. The color of all newsracks installed per this article shall be Evergreen PPL95219 or its equivalent. 
(3)  Newsracks may have a color band two and one-half (21/2) inches in height consisting of one (1) color selected by the city. Distributors may place lettering within the color band not to exceed two and one-half (21/2) inches in height on the front, sides and back of the newsrack provided such lettering is white or black in color. 
(4)  Newsracks shall carry no advertising, except the name of the publication being distributed. 
(5)  Each newsrack shall be maintained in a neat, clean condition and in good repair at all times. Specifically, but without limiting the generality of the foregoing, each newsrack shall be serviced and maintained so that: 
a.  It is reasonably free of graffiti; 
b.  It is reasonably free of dirt and grease; 
c.  It is reasonably free of chipped, faded, peeling and cracked paint in the visible painted areas thereof; 
d.  It is reasonably free of rust and corrosion in the visible metal areas thereon; 
e.  The clear plastic or glass parts thereon, if any, through which the publications are viewed are unbroken and reasonably free of cracks, dents, blemishes and discoloration; 
f.  The paper or cardboard parts or inserts thereof are reasonably free of tears, peeling or fading; 
g.  The structural parts are not broken or unduly misshapen; and 
h.  The surrounding area upon which the newsrack is placed will also be maintained in a neat and orderly condition. 
(6)  The name, address and telephone number of a responsible person who may be contacted at any time concerning the newsrack shall be displayed on the hood of the newsrack in such a manner as to be readily visible and readable to a prospective customer. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 12-8-2004) 
Sec. 33-126.1. - Prohibitions. 
    No newsrack shall be placed, installed, used or maintained: 
(a)  Within ten (10) feet of any marked crosswalk not in an intersection. 
(b)  Within the thirty-five-foot sight visibility triangle of a public or private roadway as measured along the right-of-way lines from the intersection of a public or private roadway with another roadway; and within the twenty-five-foot sight visibility triangle of a private driveway as measured along the right-of-way lines from the intersection of a public or private roadway and the edge of the private driveway. 
(c)  Within fifteen (15) feet of any fire hydrant, fire call box or other emergency facility. 
(d)  Within five (5) feet ahead of, and fifteen (15) feet of the rear of, any sign marking a designated bus stop, measured along the edge of pavement. 
(e)  At any location that does not provide a clear width of continuous passage for pedestrians of at least thirty-six (36) inches in accordance with the Americans with Disabilities Act. 
(f)  On or within two (2) feet of traffic-related signs, street lights, utility poles, bus bench or shelter. 
(g)  Facing another newsrack divided by the width of a pedestrian sidewalk or bike path. 
(h)  In the median of a divided street. 
(i)  Within one hundred fifty (150) feet of another newsrack containing the same newspaper or news periodical. 
(j)  Within three (3) feet of or in such manner as it impedes or interferes with reasonable use of any display window of any building abutting the sidewalk or such window display or access to and from a building entrance. 
(k)  In any situation where more than one (1) standard applies, the more restrictive standard shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1(17-127), 12-8-2004) 
Sec. 33-126.2. - Newsrack mounting standards. 
    Any newsrack being installed, placed, and maintained on a public right-of-way, street, or sidewalk shall comply with the following mounting standards: 
(1)  Newsracks may be mounted to an existing concrete sidewalk subject to the requirements stated in section 33-126. 
(2)  Newsrack foundations manufactured as a prefabricated concrete slab shall have a minimum three-and-one-half-inch thickness, a minimum twenty-eight-day compressive strength of two thousand five hundred (2,500) per square inch (psi). 
(3)  Newsrack foundations as a cast-in-place concrete slab shall have a minimum four-inch thickness, a minimum twenty-eight-day compressive strength of three thousand (3,000) per square inch (psi). 
(4)  A minimum one-half-inch chamfer on all concrete edges. 
(5)  A minimum three-eighths-inch diameter bolts through the four (4) corners of the newsrack pedestal base with a minimum embedment into the concrete foundations of three (3) inches. 
(6)  Newsracks shall not be chained to any tree, traffic control device, sign, bench, bus shelter or pole. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1(17-128), 12-8-2004) 
Sec. 33-126.3. - Demonstration of public need. 
(a)  Public need may be established by the following method, which is not exclusive. If another method to establish public need is desired by a publishing entity, the city and the publishing entity shall jointly determine whether the alternate method is a legitimate and accurate means to determine public usage of newsracks in question. A distributor desiring to establish public need may place an extra newsrack at a proposed location, after notice to the city, for a test period of one (1) month. No certificate of compliance will be required; however, an application must first be completed on a form provided by the department of environmental and engineering services. 
(b)  If during the one-month test period the average circulation from the newsracks equals or exceeds seventy-five (75) per cent of the capacity of the newsrack for publications published other than daily or for daily publications, the average Sunday circulation from the newsracks equals or exceeds seventy-five (75) per cent of the capacity of the newsrack, then a public need will be deemed to have been established. Assuming this extra newsrack complies with all other appropriate sections of this article, a certificate of compliance will be issued. If the extra newsrack does not comply with all other appropriate sections of this article, the deficiencies must be corrected before a certificate of compliance will be issued. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 12-8-2004) 
Sec. 33-126.4. - Enforcement procedures. 
(a)  Nonconforming racks. Within one hundred twenty (120) days after the effective date of this article [Dec. 8, 2004] and at any time thereafter, any newsrack contrary to this section of the Code shall be in violation of City Code. 
The Special Master of the City of Margate shall be authorized, pursuant to F.S. §§ 162.06(4) and 162.09(1), to find a violation of this article and require any newsracks on the public property of the City of Margate be brought into compliance with this article including, but not limited to, removal of any newsrack which is determined to be in violation, pursuant to subsection (3)b. of this section. 
(b)  [Compliance.] Each publisher or distributor of any newsrack presently placed within the City of Margate, at the time specified in the immediately preceding paragraph, shall comply with section 33-123 of this article. 
(c)  Abandonment. 
(1)  [Abandonment a violation.] In the event that a newsrack remains empty for a period of forty-five (45) continuous days, same shall be deemed abandoned, and may be treated as being in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(2)  [Voluntary abandonment.] In the event a newspaper publishing company or its distributor desires to voluntarily abandon a newsrack location, said distributor shall notify the director of DEES, completely remove the newsrack, and restore the public right-of-way to a safe and sound condition. 
(3)  [Notice.] 
a.  In the event a publisher or its distributor does not voluntarily remove a newsrack which is determined to be abandoned based upon the above, the city shall notify the publisher, in writing, giving seven (7) days to remove the identified newsrack. 
b.  Should the publisher or its distributor not remove the newsrack within the due-notice period provided, the city shall remove the newsrack and temporarily store the hardware. The publisher and/or distributor shall be responsible for paying the city its actual costs associated with the removal and storage of the newsrack prior to obtaining possession. Should the publisher or the distributor not take possession of the newsrack within ninety (90) days, the city shall consider the newsrack surplus material and dispose of it appropriately. 
(4)  Emergencies. In the event of an emergency, where the installation, use or maintenance of any newsrack poses an imminent or immediate health or safety hazard to pedestrians or vehicles, the city manager or any person designated by him shall, when feasible, give telephone notice to the newsrack owner of the nature of the emergency and afford the owner the opportunity to remove or otherwise relocate the newsrack. Where telephone notice is not feasible or where the owner fails to remove or relocate the newsrack following telephone notice of the emergency, the city manager or any person designated by him may summarily and temporarily remove or relocate such newsrack. Immediately following removal or relocation of any newsrack under these emergency procedures, the owner shall be provided written notice of the action and the nature of the emergency necessitating such action. Upon failure of the owner, following such written notice, to claim the newsrack and pay the costs of removal or relocation and storage within thirty (30) days after notice, the newsrack shall be deemed unclaimed property in possession of the city and may be disposed of pursuant to law. The owner of any newsrack may file a written request for a hearing before the city commission after an emergency removal or relocation to dispute the determination of an emergency and/or the costs or removal or relocation sought by the city, and in addition may claim and take possession of the newsrack prior to the hearing. A hearing so requested shall be granted as a matter of right. Any owner dissatisfied with the city commission's decision at such hearing may appeal such decision to a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 12-8-2004) 
Exhibit A 
City of Margate Newsrack Application Procedure 
1.  A public notice is issued that in following the amendment of the City of Margate Newsrack Ordinance (December 8, 2004) application forms and procedures will be available at the department of environmental and engineering services. 
2.  The city manager has assigned the department of engineering and environmental services to issue and coordinate the permitting of the newsrack ordinance. 
3.  For the next thirty (30) calendar days, subsequent to the approval of the newsrack ordinance, all applicants shall submit an application identifying the intersecting streets and street addresses where they wish to install newsracks. The City of Margate will process the applications on a first-come, first-served basis to establish preferred location(s). 
4.  Within ten (10) calendar days after the said thirty-day submittal period, the city will develop a master map for newsracks and provide each applicant with the intersection in which there are multiple requests, along with the identification of the other applicants. 
5.  The city will review the final applications and provide a certificate of compliance to conforming applications or a denial with cause (and suggest possible alternate locations, where available) within seven (7) calendar days. 
6.  The applicant will advise the city on the commencement of construction by providing a forty-eight-hour notice. The city will send an engineering inspector to perform a preliminary inspection. A final inspection will be performed by the engineering inspector at the completion of the job. 
7.  The applicant will have a total of ninety (90) days from the approval of the application to bring all existing newsracks into compliance. 
8.  After said initial forty-day period, additional preliminary applications will be accepted for all newsracks and processed within five (5) business days. Upon receipt of the application, the city will provide a certificate of compliance to conforming applications or a denial with cause (and suggest possible alternate locations, where available) within five (5) business days. 
(Ord. No. 2004-19, § 1, 12-8-2004) 

Exhibit B
ARTICLE XI. - ALARM SYSTEMS 

Sec. 33-127. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to encourage security alarm users and alarm businesses (sales, installation, customer service and/or monitoring) to maintain the operational reliability and the proper use of alarm systems in limiting unnecessary police emergency responses to false alarms/alarm malfunctions. 
(b)  This article governs alarm systems, requires permits, establishes fees, provides for violations, creates a system of administration, and sets conditions for suspension or loss of permit. 
(Ord. No. 96-17, § 1, 11-6-1996; Ord. No. 98-9, § 1, 7-1-1998) 
Sec. 33-128. - Definitions. 
    [For the purposes of this article, certain terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise.] 
    Alarm administrator shall mean the chief of police or his/her designee. 
    Alarm coordinator shall mean a person or persons selected by the Chief of Police of the City of Margate to coordinate, control and review alarm applications, permits and false alarm notifications. 
    Alarm notification shall mean a notification intended to summon the police, which is designed either to be initiated purposefully by a person or by an alarm system that responds to a stimulus characteristic of unauthorized intrusion. At the discretion of the alarm coordinator, multiple false alarm/alarm malfunction notifications in a twenty-four-hour period of time may be counted as only one (1) false alarm notification. 
    Alarm site shall mean a single premises or location served by an alarm system or systems. 
    Alarm system shall mean a device or system that emits, transmits, or relays a signal intended to summon, or that would reasonably be expected to summon police services of the city, including but not limited to local alarms. Alarm system does not include: 
(1)  An alarm installed on a vehicle unless the vehicle is permanently located at a site; or 
(2)  An alarm designed to alert only the inhabitants of a premises that does not have a local alarm. 
    Alarm user means a person(s), firm, partnership, corporation, association, organization, company, or other entity in control of a premises where an alarm system is located. 
    Calendar year means a twelve-month period beginning on the date the alarm permit is issued. 
    Chief of police means the City of Margate Chief of Police or his/her designee. 
    City means the City of Margate, Florida. 
    City manager means the City of Margate City Manager, or his/her designee. 
    False alarm means activation or transmission of any alarm signal caused by human error, mechanical or electronic malfunction, negligence of the alarm user or the alarm user's employee, whether or not the exact cause of the alarm activation is determined, or any other activation or transmission of any alarm signal where no actual or attempted burglary or robbery exist. Severe weather, power outages, transmission line malfunctions, acts of God, malicious acts of persons under the control of the user, or any other cause clearly beyond the control of the alarm user will be considered in determining if an alarm activation was false and whether or not any fee, warning or other punitive action will be taken against the alarm user as provided for by this article. 
    Local alarm shall mean an alarm system that emits a signal at an alarm site that is audible or visible from the exterior of a structure. 
    Notice means written notice given by personal service upon the addressee, or, given by the United States Post Office, postage paid, to the addressee's last known mailing address. 
    Permit holder shall mean the person designated in the application as required in section 33-129(c)(1) below, who is responsible for responding to alarms and giving access to the site, and who is responsible for maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees. 
    Person shall mean an individual, corporation, partnership, association, organization, or similar entity. 
(Ord. No. 96-17, § 1, 11-6-1996; Ord. No. 98-9, § 1, 7-1-1998) 
Sec. 33-129. - Permit required; application; fee; transferability; false statements. 
(a)  A person commits a violation of the City Code if he/she operates or causes to be operated an alarm system without a valid permit issued by the city. A separate permit is required for each alarm system. 
(b)  Upon receipt of a completed application form and a non-refundable administrative permit fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00), the city shall issue an alarm permit to an applicant unless an applicant: 
(1)  Failed to pay a fee assessed under section 33-137 below; or 
(2)  Had an alarm permit for the alarm site revoked, and the violation causing the revocation has not been corrected. 
(c)  Each permit application must include the following information, which should be updated each time any of the following information changes: 
(1)  The name, address and telephone numbers of the person who will be the permit holder and be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees assessed under this section;
